Review Contents: First let me say that I suffer a serious hearing loss which makes it difficult to watch television with my wife because I have to have the volume up so loud and even then I can't hear everything.  I have had two sets of sennheiser RS 120's for a few years now and loved them.  My wife wanted to get me these for Christmas this year because they were apparently capable of surround sound. Now I'm not an audiophile but I will try to point out some pro's and con's here.The 175's are an over the ear fit as opposed to the 120's being an on the ear fit.  The 175's fit much tighter which is very nice when up and moving about yet the tight fit makes it difficult to hear when my wife is speaking to me during a show which she does quite often.  I'll let you decide if that's is a pro or a con.  The 120's were loose enough that I could hear her speak even though I still had to remove the headset to understand her.  The looseness had a downside though in that if I went to the fridge for a drink or snack and bent down the headset fell off.  Not so with the 175's.  Both sets have excellent sound reproduction even though the 120's are analog.  The 175's can be digital or analog which can be decided by a switch on the back of the transmitter.  You have the option of connecting to the sound source by optical cable or 3.5 jack which in my case required a y adapter converting to RCA jacks.  I was amazed to find that there is a very noticeable difference between digital and analog, digital being the best by far.  With the digital you don't hear any static or interference noises in non-dialog or silent spots.  At least I couldn't hear any and my wife said in her words "this is fantastic".sound with the 175's:You can switch between regular stereo, low SRS, and High SRS by clicking a button on the side of the headset.  This can also be controlled at the transmitter.  There is a very noticeable difference between each setting.  I have noticed that on low SRS the background recordings seem to be moved back and reduced in volume while the main dialog remains at regular volume.  Ever had one of those instances where the main character is talking in a whisper voice, which seems to be in vogue these days, and is suddenly overrun by the background noise, which also seems to be a problem these days.  Well, low SRS helps to overcome that problem for me.  I can hear the dialog very clearly and if you've lived for a while having to constantly asked "what did he/she say?"  then you can really appreciate that fact.In High SRS there is a distinct surround sound quality.  I've never been able to experience this before due to my hearing loss so to me it is awesome.  I love Paul Simons music, especially "Graceland", "father and daughter" and "late in the evening".  I just thought I liked them before but after listening to them through the 175's I have heard notes and instruments that I didn't realize were there. Now I love the songs.  Having discovered that I went back and watched a couple of my favorite movies and discovered background sounds that I had been missing and they add so much more to the entertainment value.  Keep in mind that I have experienced all this with the 120's also and there is a large difference.continued pros sound aside:I like that the controls are on the side of the 175 headset because I often recline when watching television and this keeps the controls from contacting anything and changing the settings unintentionally.This was a problem with the 120 sets because the controls were behind the headset.The 175 set, to me, is much more comfortable because of the padding and because possibly of the tighter fit which keeps them in place verses the loose fit of the 120 set.cons (maybe):The 175 set is only capable of employing two headsets.The 120 can employ several at one time.  I'm not sure how many but certainly more than four because I have that many headsets.The 120 has an option of three channels selectable on the transmitter and the headset which means you can use more than one in a household without interfering with each other.  This is the situation at my house.  I have one set in the bedroom and one in the living room and we can use them separately on separate channels at the same time.  My grandkids love the headsets so this settles a problem when they come to visit and want cartoons while I want news.The 175 has only one channel so this setup would probably not be possible.The 175 power button has to be held down for about three seconds to activate while the 120 has a slide switch.  The 175 has a very slight delay between activation and transmitter connection.  The 120 is instant.  This caused a rather humorous incident early on.  My wife was watching a movie on Netflix and I picked up the headset, turned it on, placed it on my head and thought I was waiting on a connection when in reality I was in a very quite point in the movie just before an explosion and massive gunfire.  I was on my way to my recliner when all hell broke loose and it was so realistic I almost wet my pants and overran the recliner.  It was apparently the highlight of my wife's day.  She still laughs about it.  Her lack of concern about my bruised shins and ego aside...after the fact it was funny.I know this was lengthy but I hope it helps someone in my situation to make an informed decision.In  short I would never had purchased the 175's for myself due to the cost because I wouldn't have believed they would make this much difference.  Now that I've experienced them I would buy them in a heartbeat.Now a word about sennheiser's customer service.  I had a situation early on where I lost the optical connection with my TV.  I was quick to blame the new headset simply because they were new.  I sent an email to sennheiser  in hopes they could find a solution before I had to send the set back.  I had a return mail in about 45 minutes telling me what to do.  Turns out the problem was with the television and not the sennheiser transmitter.  Quick response, great customer service.
Title: These are fantastic but I'm not retiring my 120's.

Review Contents: I originally started shopping for wireless headphones to find something better than the so-called TV ears that a member of my immediate family who suffers from hearing loss had been using with some success. This inevitably brought me to the fine line of quality wireless headphones available from the German company Sennheiser and I had first thought about purchasing a just recently discontinued RS 170 or RS 180 model without an optical connection â€“ analog only (As of 05/30/2015, the RS 180 was still only $199.99 at Crutchfield online with free shipping and 60-day returns). But then why spend about $200.00 on technology that is essentially 12 to 14 years old when the absolutely latest thing from Sennheiser (models RS 165, RS 175, RS 185 and RS 195) is available for just a little bit more?Out of this latest line of Sennheiser wireless headphones with a two-year warranty it is this model â€“ the closed-back RS 175 â€“ that I eventually ended up purchasing from Crutchfield online. Pricing was exactly the same as it is here on Amazon.com ($279.95). However, by using my Discover card (5% rebate through Shop Discover online and 90-day price match guarantee - lowest price seen 2 weeks later was $233.97) I was able to ultimately get my pair of brand new headphones for only $219.97 with free shipping, no sales tax and 60-day returns.I agree with CNET.com and their excellent review of the Sennheiser RS 175 that it is this specific model that gives you the most bang for your buck; it is the most cost-effective model in this product line. There is a big difference in moving from the RS 165 to the RS 175 in that the transmission distance of the RS 165 is only rated at about 90 feet while the RS 175 and other models are still functional at a distance of about 300 feet. The RS 175 also adds a low/high surround sound capability which the RS 165 (bass boost feature only) does not have.The differences in moving to a pricier model beyond the RS 175 are not that significant, in my opinion. Whether the open-back (not as sound isolating) RS 185 with the addition of manual/automatic level control features (MLC/ALC) and a balance control located on the headset is worth an additional $90.00 premium (best current price of about $370.00) above the RS 175 is something that only you can decide.At a cost of about $170.00 more than the RS 175, the top-of-the-line RS 195 closed-back model includes all of the aforementioned features of the RS 185 and adds 7 presets to tailor sound to individual hearing requirements as well as separate â€œspeechâ€ and â€œmusicâ€ modes.Initial setup of these RS 175 headphones was extremely simple. The most time-consuming step was waiting for the batteries located in the two headphone ear-cups to complete their initial charging process which takes about 18 hours; subsequent full recharging of the headphones should only take about 8 hours. The operating time with fully charged headphones is claimed to be up to 18 hours until recharging is required. Both analog and optical/digital connection options are available. You can choose to use both connections (say for a TV and a stereo system) and then toggle between the two at your leisure using the sliding switch provided for this purpose on the back of the headphone transmitter.So far I have only opted to connect my television via the included 1.5 m long optical cable (donâ€™t forget to remove both clear protective plastic end caps before using) and the optical input on the headphone transmitter which ensures optimum performance. If the cable is too short for your needs, you can always subsequently purchase a 3 m long cable like I did for about $10.00 (AmazonBasics Digital Optical Audio Toslink Cable - 9.8 Feet [3 Meters] - see my review). Note that the appropriate output on the back of your TV or other device may not be labelled as an optical output: Mine is actually called the digital audio output, but it is definitely what is needed to make the proper connection. The unique shape of the optical connector (it really can only fit in one place) will help you figure out just where it needs to go, assuming that you have an appropriate output available and donâ€™t need to make an analog connection. If you do make an optical/digital audio connection to your TV, be sure to go into the appropriate settings menu before first using the headphones to set the optical/digital audio output mode to PCM (pulse-code modulation). Donâ€™t leave it on automatic or some other setting. This is specifically required in the 15-language Sennheiser instruction manual on CD that comes with the headphones!As far as the user experience itself is concerned, these comfortable headphones with the easily adjustable headband are just what I was looking for. The member of my family who is hard of hearing has noticed a day and night difference in his ability to not only hear, but more importantly distinguish and understand speech when using these wonderfully isolating closed-back headphones. There is virtually no sound leakage in or out. He remains happily occupied in his own little world watching TV while now being able to understand essentially everything. This was not the case with the previously mentioned TV ears that cost less than $100.00 when purchased. Other people in the same room can simultaneously watch the TV in the usual manner â€“ without headphones. Everybodyâ€™s happy.The quality of the sound that emanates from these headphones when using an optical connection is truly amazing! There is absolutely no hissing or other distracting sound â€“ only that which needs to be heard and nothing more. The bass boost setting is quite useful for music and can be activated on-the fly when needed by using the touch controls located on the outside of the right ear-cup (bass boost, surround sound, volume +/-) near where the on/off button for the headphones is found. The surround sound setting (off, low and high available) does create a more immersive sound experience when activated; I personally prefer the low setting and usually have the headphones set in this manner when I use them. Additional bass boost and surround sound controls, each with a separate indicator light that glows green when activated, are also found on the front of the headphone transmitter upon which the headphones are placed when not in use and for recharging. The transmission distance with these headphones is excellent: I am able to walk anywhere throughout my 1600 square foot ranch home without any signal loss whatsoever; the same holds true when I am in either my front or back yards.I have the headphone transmitter base located near my Roku 3 in the living room and there is absolutely no interference when streaming and simultaneously using the Sennheiser headphones. However, I should note that I have my Roku 3 set to stream at 5.0 GHz on my dual-band AC router. There may or may not be a problem if your WiFi network with connected devices located near the Sennheiser transmitter is set to function in the 2.4 to 2.8 GHz range which is used by the headphones. Youâ€™ll just have to try it and see what happens. If necessary, appropriate device relocation - a greater distance of separation - should resolve any difficulties.Overall my hearing-impaired family member and I have been exceedingly pleased with our listening experience when using these Sennheiser RS 175, closed-back, wireless headphones of impressive quality. If you too would like to experience a most enjoyable, crystal-clear earful when partaking of diverse auditory pleasures during your leisure time, I can recommend them most highly and without any reservations whatsoever.
Title: An ear-opening experience whether or not you are hearing impaired

Review Contents: I bought these to replace a pair of Sony MDR RF-6000s and use them mostly for TV/Movies.  The Sonys cut out and picked up lots of interference from wifi and other 2.4ghz traffic (I live in a city environment with easily 25 wifi networks in range).  Overall, they've been great and are well worth the money.Signal:So far, the Sennheisers have been flawless with no dropouts or signal loss.  As above, I live in a pretty interference-heavy environment.  Haven't really range tested them, but they'll easily go into the next room with no problem.Sound Quality:I played around with the bass boost and surround, but find things sound best with all that off.  There's no shortage of bass and sound quality is full and on par with any high-end headphone from Bose, Sennheiser, or Sony.  There's a slight signal delay, though that's only perceptible when the audio is also playing through speakers, and I'd expect that from any RF headphones.Batteries:I haven't tested the battery life yet (had them on a couple hours and no issues).  They use rechargeable AAA batteries, which allows for the use of standard AAAs if the rechargeable ones die.  Each earcup has a battery, accessible by twisting/unlocking the pad.  That evens out the weight, but adds a step to change batteries.Cradle/Transponder:It's a pretty sleek looking stand, both with the phones on and off.  Takes a little bit of practice to get them on and off just right, but nothing too difficult.Comfort:They're a pretty tight fit, which is good for keeping them on while moving around, though maybe not the best for all-day listening.  All considered, no complaints about comfort.  My only long-term concern would be the foam pads on the headband - foam tends to wear and these don't look replaceable.  The headband is a standard adjustable model, though a bit thicker than some others due to the larger size and weight of the electronics/batteries.  The Sonys had a band that turned them on automatically when you put them on (and then beeped annoyingly if there was no signal).  These use a button for on/off, which is slightly less convenient but more durable and reliable long term.  You have to hold the button for a few secs, so they aren't prone to accidentally being turned off.In all, these are a good buy and decent balance between price and quality with no significant flaws.  My main driver is signal quality in a high-interference environment, and these have certainly solved that so far.  Also, the packaging and instructions were easy and clearly well thought out.  That's often an afterthought, but a bad experience there can set the tone for the product long term.  Nice work, Sennheiser.UPDATE: 10 Months in, and these are still going strong.  Battery life is still excellent - I've had a few "marathon" sessions (use these for TV) and they've yet to run out.  Often, I get lazy and don't throw them back on the charger after an evening of TV and they're still good to go the next time.  In our old place, I finally found where the signal would cut out - in the basement three floors down.  Our new house is lath and plaster, which is murder on all kinds of wireless signals, and they're good for about one floor in either direction and probably 70-80 ft from the base station.  Unless you live with lath & plaster (and you'll know if you do) or in a stone castle, I can't imagine a scenario where you wouldn't have whole-house roaming.  Still never had even a blip of interference, despite a neighborhood of wireless routers screaming at high volume in 2.4ghz.
Title: Great Wireless Headphones

Review Contents: After much research, I finally pulled the trigger on 11/22/15 and ordered the top rated Sennheiser RS 175 Headphones over the ear phoneswith  Amazon Prime for $245, with no added tax or shipping costs. These were essential for domestic tranquility with others in the house because my new SAMSUNG 4K UHDTV and Soundbar system speaker bass which you could hear all over the house even with a low volume setting of 10.  These got as low as $199  for Black Friday, but I still got a good price on them.General Comments:As far as the hookup to my Samsung UN65JS8500 (see my Amazon review)......a couple of things your should know that took me about an hour to figure out which might save you some time and pain. First,  I already had a Samsung Soundbar on the 4K UHDTV which ran off the single optical out from the one-connect mini box.  These headphones are not Bluetooth but have their own wireless frequency transmitter direct to your headphones up to 100 meters away depending on your walls. You don't have to pair them up with the UHDTV and you can get a second pair of them for a viewing companion. They are great phones but you need to set them up special on this Samsung:1. Split the Optical out into 2 cables if you have a soundbar. Get the Toslink Digital Optical Audio Splitter 1x3...1 input to 3 possible output devices. The VHD-TS1X3 will cost you around $25 on Prime or at stores like Fry's. Also purchase a 1 meter optical cable from your one-connect mini box to the splitter input port for about $10, Then you will have A, B, or C output ports and supplied cables from the splitter to your soundbar, headphones, and one additional device if you need it.2. On the Samsung Menu Sound Option. Very important, as it took me an hour to figure out what settings to use as my first hookup with the headphones was dead silent and there was nobody to help me at Samsung or Sennheiser:a. Sound Mode: Up to you, but I like "Movie" for the better base in most movies and 4K series on Prime or Netflix.b. TV Speaker: Stay with SoundBar (if you have one) or TV speakers....not Bluetooth, or Optical Out options.c. Additional Settings: HDMI Out:.....set to PCM and Audio Format: also set to PCM. Headphones require PCM format on UHDTV.Once you do this, the headphones and the soundbar will both send out fantastic audio simultaneously......so you must mute the soundbar (or regular TV speakers) to eliminate any echo effect time delays....but fiber optic is so fast you should not hear any. My Audio delay is set to 100 ms with my HD Audio: OFF. You may need to play with these depending on your speaker/Soundbar setup.PROS:1. Great sound fidelity and reproduction.  No noise once you put them on.  You hear voices and stereo sound effects you can't hear fromstandard UHDTV speakers or soundbars which adds to your viewing experience.2.  I can take them to any room in the house within 30 feet upstairs or downstairs and not miss a sound.  No sound dropouts anywhere,even the garage, bathroom, or outside.3.  Fairly easy to setup once you have your optical cable or stereo audio cable setup and your sound source menu options setup properlyfor the Sennheiser.4.  Nice to have the transmitter post nearby to charge the headphones when not in use and red/green charging indicator status.5. Good reference CD.  I suggest you print out the entire 32 page instruction manual before you start the setup or view the PDF.  You can still read every page if you double up to print 2 pages per sheet for 16 pages with landscape format.  It will take you 10 minutes to read it.6.  Nice to confirm your current BASS BOOST or SURROUND SOUND setting lights on the transmitter post if within view.7.  I am still experimenting with BASS and Surround Sound settings Hi and Low for movies, normal shows, and music channels.  So far, I like the just the extra BASS BOOST setting for movies.  You need to experiment for yourself.CONS:1.  Headphone batteries:  Swap out the supplied AAA batteries with the Energizer AAA rechargeable batteries, which charge up much faster and last a lot longer than the German supplied "ReCyko" batteries. You need 1 battery in for the left and right side headphone. Volume controls, + or -, base high/low, and surround sound buttons are on the right side headphone, which take a while to get use to. Don't use your remote or you will unmute your soundbar or TV speakers and alert others in your house and defeat your headphone privacy.2.  All controls on the right earphone.  Very nice if you are right-handed or ok with your right hand if left-handed.  The other problem is that the 4 main quadrants of the control circle:  BASS,  SURROUND SOUND,  VOL -, and VOL +, are basically on a flat surface, and  unless you have a mutant eye or good tactile feel on your right thumb, you really can't feel which control is which.  The first few days, I had to take off my headphones multiple times to see which control I was touching.  Problem solved:  I got some 3/8" round soft felt tabs with a stick-on side on each control.  The BASS and SURROUND tabs are a little thicker than the sound control tabs, so I could feel, where I was on the control circle.  All I had to remember was the BASS was to the left of the SURROUND control and that VOL - was to the left of VOL +.  Sennheiser should improve this ergonomic problem with future models.3.  Break-in pain.  I have only had these headphones about 2 weeks, and even with the padding around the ears and on the top of my head, there is definitely a dull throbbing pain around my ears once I remove the headphones after about an hour of viewing.  There is  no way to adjust the tightness of these phones on the sides of your head.  However, as others have suggested, it might take a month or so of normal use to loosen them up...or maybe you can stretch them out over a large wooden block when not in use.I may change my 4* rating to 5* in a future review update if the pain issue resolves itself or my head shrinks.  We'll see.
Title: Very Happy with this Addition to my 4K Samsung System with a few Suggestions

Review Contents: I'm a musician with a home studio.  With several sets of headphones all getting old, I decided to invest in some new ones. I've had good luck with Sennheiser in the past so I wanted to check out what they were currently offering. After reading lots of reviews, I decided to give these rs175 rf's a try. I was a little leery of them being wireless but trusting in the Sennheiser name, bought them anyway. I wanted them for general recording and playback.Pros: Excellent sound... flat, uncolored. Clear detailed, etc. All the qualities I've come to expect from Sennheiser.  Wireless setup was virtually nothing... plug in the base where you'd plug in the headphones and you're done. Turn on the headphones and start listening. The stand serves as the charging station and placing the headphones on it is straightforward and secure... not clumsy at all. I have a fairly large head with proportional sized ears... (size xxl hat). The ear pads fit completely over my ears and completely seal very nicely around them.  You won't be bothered by outside sounds, nor will your spouse be bothered by what you're listening to.  A quick check of the range shows I can go anywhere in my average size home without losing the signal. (I didn't try going outside).Cons: The only negative is that there is a bit of latency. If you use them for listening to music or even tv, you won't notice it... but if you turn on speakers at the same time and listen to both, you'll notice a very slight lag in the headphones.Bottom line: these are excellent headphones, quality of build and quality of sound are both first rate. But if that latency is an issue, you probably shouldn't be looking at wireless anyway (I suspect this occurs on any wireless system).
Title: Great sounding wireless headphones...

Review Contents: I got a newer Samsung TV (2016) and it only had optical out for audio.  Tried to keep my old Sennheiser running with a Orei DA34X Optical to Audio RCA jack converter.  Mistake, if you are still at the decision point just go straight to these.  The Oreiâ€™s Would run for 20 minutes, go mute, and I had to power cycle them to get the audio back.  The optical input here directly to the headset base seems very solid. Right now this is the lowest end Sennheiser that takes an optical input.  Havenâ€™t owned them long but Iâ€™m pretty sure they will be very stable in terms of providing good audio for hours at a time.  I have a sound bar that wants optical too.  An Optical splitter might be good but I donâ€™t know if there is an optical splitter.  Two other comments about the product.  The sound is very good, especially for spoken dialog.  Some have commented about the on/off switch.  With the old Sennheiser it was easy to know whether the headset was on or off.  Be patient with the power on for these.  It takes a few seconds after you hit the button for them to power up.  Once they are on a quick hit of the on button will mute them and another quick hit will restore the sound without turning off the base station.  Update, connecting to comcast worked great for these.  Want to mention something I ran into so that others can avoid.  I have a 2016 Samsung 9000 level tv.  When I went to Amazon using the tv remote the green lite on the front of the sennheiser started blinking.  The green light blinking means the Sennheiser base station isnâ€™t talking to the tv.  I was confused because the sennheiser worked great with comcast.  in the Samsung settings -> Sound -> Expert settings my default for HDMI Audio Format was PCM which is good.  BUT! The Audio Format below that has to be PCM also and itâ€™s default was Dolby Digital.  When I set Audio Format to PCM also Amazon, Netflix, and YouTube started putting sound through the Sennheiser.
Title: RS 175 Optical Input Discussion, Samsung/amazon only audio problem

Review Contents: Outstanding sound, would have given this 5 stars if it had a control for the treble as well as the base. I have read many reviews complaining about aThe lack of a charging system if you purchase a 2nd set of these headphones. The price difference between buying the whole system and buying just the headphones is $20. If you want two headsets, buy two complete systems, only attach one base to the audio sorce and use the 2nd base as a charger. No shuffling headsets on one base or switching out batteries and you have a spare base if anything goes wrong with the main one. Works like a charm and the convenience of two chargers is well worth the $20.
Title: Buy two complete systems if you want two headsets

Review Contents: Wireless:When sitting at my desk near the transmitter the signal is clear. However after I step out of my room about 15ft there is a lot of interference and I can no longer listen to a song/podcast properly until I return within range. I should mention that I live in an apartment complex and it may or may not be a factor.2 inputs Analog & Digital:I picked the rs 175 because it has two inputs, unlike the rs 165 which only had analog. I initially planned to use the analog 3.5mm input for my computer and the digital input for my T.V. and just flip the switch on the dock when I want to watch T.V./Computer. However the analog input consistently introduced an annoying flat lining noise and was unusable. I tried it with my desktop, several different phones and my laptop and the same noise was introduced with each device. Luckily the digital optical worked well and is very clear compared to the analog input. So as a result in order for me to switch back and forth between tv/computer I have to unplug/re-plug the digital opt from each device.Comfort:When I first tried on these headphones there is some pressure on jawline and on the top of my head. I like to transition from youtube to playing games to watching T.V./Movies so I was using these headphones for long periods of time. After 3-4 hours it became uncomfortable/sore. I would have to take the headphones off and take a break.Sound:I am by no means an audiophile/expert, but I am going to try my best to describe the sound. Iâ€™ve listen to podcasts, hip-hop, edm, and music with strong vocals. Iâ€™ve also watched a couple movies and binge watched some anime with these headphones. Overall I would describe the sound as very upfront, powerful, and clear. For me personally, I thought it was a bit overwhelming and didnâ€™t like the sound. The best way I can describe it, the audio sounded very in my face, it felt suffocating and sometimes gave me a head ache.  Every sound instrument, beat, and vocal sounded like it was 5ft  away from me and in a way sounded artificial. I donâ€™t know if this is the correct term but I believe what I am describing is a lack of depth. I also tried testing out the bass boost and surround options a couple times but didnâ€™t test them for long periods because I thought the audio sounded better overall without these settings on. I just want to say that sound can be very subjective in terms of what people like and although I may not have like the way these headphones sounded you just might.Battery & Charging Dock:The battery life was never an issue and I loved the charging station. I never really felt like I had to actually "charge" these headphones, every time I was done using them I felt as if I was simply putting them away. I usually just lay my headphones down on my desk but I always worry they might get scratched or banged up so the dock was nice and really convenient. The only problem I had was with the initial charge time. As soon as I got the headphones I wanted to try them out immediately, but they require an initial 16 hour charge time. I was trying to keep myself busy and take my mind off them but I would find myself checking back every couple of hours for the green light.
Title: I really like these headphones they look awesome on my desk, but they didnâ€™t quiet perform like I expected them to.

Review Contents: These work great.  I have them in my home office and in my living room.  Pricey?  Yes, but absolutely worth it!  In the living room, I have connected the base station to the audio output on my TV.  (You will have to purchase an inexpensive RCA male to 3.5 mm female convert to do this.)  You can also plug directly into the headphone jack (most TVs have one), but you will probably lose the sound from the TV speakers.  With my set up, I can get sound from the TV speakers at the same time as the headphones.  This is great, because my wife likes the sound lower.  The range is fabulous because the signal is not blocked by walls, interior or exterior.  In fact, I keep mine in a closed cabinet!  Also, these headphones use rechargeable AAA batteries.  Some Sennheiser products use a proprietary rechargeable battery.  These are expensive to replace and seem to have a shorter run time than ordinary AAA's.  Whenever I purchase battery powered electronics, I try to buy products that use standard battery sizes (e.g., AA or AAA) rather than proprietary products, which are always pricey!I find the headphones to be very comfortable.  The sound is fine too whether it comes from TV, DVD, VCR.  That includes music as well.  Maybe not theater quality, but the product has 2 surround sound settings (3 if you include "Off"!) and a bass booster.  And there is plenty of volume.  (If you need more volume, then use the headphone jack.  This will allow you to increase the volume by increasing the volume on the TV in addition to the volume on the headphones.  Nice, if you need that much volume.)I find the headphones to be comfortable.  The control buttons on the right hand headset are a bit tricky to operate by feel, but you can always take them off to make an adjustment.  With a little time, I can now access the controls by touch, so give it a chance.  You know, I might even by a third pair for the bedroom!
Title: EXCELLENT CORDLESS HEADPHONES!

Review Contents: This unit was a cinch to hook up. The headphones fit snug to my head and seals in sound perfectly but not very comfortable to wear. I find that I need to take frequent breaks removing the headphones as it feels like a vice on my head. Perhaps that's a trade off I can live with. The sound caps at a reasonable level and I love the surround sound feature. It really does take 16 hours for the initial charge and I suggest you don't skimp on this as you will notice shorter battery times later. The headphones are strong/sturdy with the accompanying weight. It comes with a digital optical cord but I highly recommend purchasing a longer cord if your unit is placed away from your TV or cable-box. Sennheiser makes solid, great sounding audio products that's on par with highend industry standards. The only reason that I did not give a five rating is the lack of comfort and that a AAA battery is needed for each headphone. I will continue testing these and update this review in a few weeks.
Title: The headphones fit snug to my head and seals in sound perfectly but not very comfortable to wear

Review Contents: I own the Seinnheiser RS170, and two of the RS175, in different locations.  While the sound is similar, the 170 requires activating a switch on the base unit, then the headphone.  The 175 requires only a button press (4 seconds or so) on the headphone, which then activates the base station.While my 70+ yr ears are not audiophile quality, I find the sound quality quite good.  I also find that I can understand speech rather well with the earphones -- not always true from my soundbar.I also find the earphones (both 170 and 175) to be comfortable, occasionally for 4-5 hour periods.Both the k170 and 175 take the same replacement earpads.  I have had my 170 for 2-1/2 years, using it in my exercise room (i.e., sweating into the earpads), and have found no degradation at all.  My 175's are about a year younger, again, with no degradation in the earpad.  Sennheiser OEM earpads are about $17.While I don't normally run the battery out, I have found no battery issues in any of the thee sets that I use.  One set sits on the charger sometimes for a month (remote location) before use -- again with no issues.  The others are used frequently -- daily or bi-daily, again with no battery issues.  Of course, the AAA NiCad batteries are easily replaced, with they finally wear out.  A good charger will keep NiCad batteries for quite a long time.  The biggest battery issue is running the batteries all the way down, which places reverse current in the weaker of the two batteries, effectively killing it.Bottom line is that I liked them enough to put one on each sound device that I use.  Good sound and reliable operation.
Title: Decent sound and reliable operation.

Review Contents: Oh how I wish I had bought these a long time ago. My husband is hard of hearing even with his hearing aids. TV was nightmare as he couldn't understand people and even the captioning wasn't always helpful as they skip words, misspell them or put up gibberish when it was too fast. Often the sound had to be so loud for him I was afraid of losing my hearing. I gave him the headphones for Christmas and it's been a miracle for us. He can now hear and understand movies and tv. When he wants to watch something I don't care about, I can turn the sound off and he can hear it just fine. No cords and works even if he gets up to go to the kitchen. He has the stand sitting next to the TV and when not in use he puts the headphones on there to keep them charged up. I would recommend these to anyone who has hearing problems.
Title: Marriage saver

Review Contents: Like a lot of people, I had the RS 110. It lasted 9 years, including when I set it aside thinking it was dead, randomly plugged it back after it being disconnected for a couple of days and it started working again! It lasted about 3 years after that. Guess it just needed recharging. Needless to say, I was ready to buy another Sennheiser product when the RS110 died for good. After researching all of the models, I chose the RS 175 model for its price and the overall positive feedback. I was a little reluctant, as some people mentioned the digital signal could cut out, but I decided it was the best choice. So far, so good and overall I like it but there are some quirks. Here's what I've found:Pros:-- Good, solid sound. I like the fact the headphones cover my ears and the ear pads are comfortable. I use it solely on my computer and do sometimes sit farther away (10 feet or so) to watch a movie or TV show. Unlike the RS110, it didn't start to fade a little as I got a certain distance away. No analog static here. I have walked out of my apartment and could still hear sound coming from the phones, although it did stop at a certain point (no listening to music in the laundry room). I sometimes wear them in my kitchen or when walking around my apartment while listening to music, and the headphones work great for that. No loss of signal at all.-- It turns the sound off after a set period and it's easy to turn back on with a quick flick of the button (as long as the power light is still on on the headphones --- see Cons for a caveat about that)-- It's easy to put back onto the charging station and I've never run out of power when using the headphones off the charger for a time.This is due to the power saving feature which, as mentioned below, can be a bit frustrating.Cons:-- The volume buttons on the side of the headphones are somewhat tricky to use without taking off the headphones. I sometimes turn it down when I mean to turn it up if I try to adjust the volume with them on. I have to feel around a bit for the volume buttons to get it right and sometimes turn on the surround sound or bass boost by mistake, but don't do it as much now that I've gotten used to them. Another reviewer mentioned this and fixed it by putting some type of raised sticker on one of the buttons. I may do this.-- Speaking of the Bass boost and surround sound, it doesn't do a whole lot for my set up. This might be more of a benefit on a higher end system or high-quality TV, but it doesn't add much to my onboard computer sound card.-- The headphones fully cover your ears, and when it's warm your ears can get a bit sweaty. Not a huge problem though unless I'm using them a lot for long periods.-- And the power issue. Sometimes the headphones are hard to turn back on if I've put them down, and not back on the charger/receiver, and don't run sound through them for a longer period. The headphones do power down completely after not running sound through them for longer periods (which is great for not running out of juice) and, unlike when the power button on the headphones stays lit and you simply hit the power button on the headphones quickly to restore sound, if the power light goes off on the headphones, as well as the connectivity light on the charger/receiver, it sometimes doesn't play sound when you turn them back on. How it works to turn them on is you have to hold the power button on the headphones until the power light comes on the headphones and then a connectivity light comes on on the charger/receiver. It works fine when you first turn them on after taking them off the charger/receiver, but for some reason when you leave the phones lying around, and off the charger/receiver, and the lights do go off ( I don't know the actual time it takes for this) on both the headphones and the charger/receiver, it won't play sound when you turn it back on again, even if both lights are lit. As mentioned before, not a problem if the lights stay on when you leave the headphones off the charger and don't run sound through them: just hit the power button on the headphones once quickly and sound plays. It's interesting, as doing the same thing after you power the phones back on and they don't play sometimes fixes the issue, but not always. Occasionally, I have to turn them completely off again and then back on to get it to work. I've noticed the problem can be inconsistent too. Sometimes I can watch as the power button comes on on the headphones ( of course you can't be wearing them at the time) and then the light comes on the charger/receiver, it will run sound if you let go of the power button on the headphones just as the light comes on on the receiver, but again not always. It definitely won't work if you leave the headphones on, press the power button on the headphones and wait for the light on the charger/receiver to come on. You end up holding the power button on the headphones on for too long or something. No sound will come through. This is when I have to power them down and then back up again as even pressing the power button on the headphones quickly doesn't always work.  This may be by design, and it might just be a timing issue, but it doesn't do it when you first turn on the headphones after taking them off the charger so it's kind of annoying.Again, overall the headphones are well made and the sound is solid. Despite the minor quirks of the powering down kind, I would probably buy them again. For the price, I think they are worth it.
Title: Very happy overall but some minor problems

Review Contents: Another Sennheiser great product! In full disclosure I own corded Sennheiser headphones and personally would not buy anything else because of the quality and sound. On that note these are no exception they are cordless and they sound absolutely tremendous. You can read the reviews for yourself and you be glad to find out that they are a Hi-Fi item. They come with surround sound and also extra Bass. They are easy to hook up to your TV. Just hook the optical optical cord to your TV and then to the back of the headphone unit. Let the headphones charge for 16 hours. The volume rocker and other controls are on the right side for easy handling. We bought these for our seventy-year-old mother and she absolutely adores them in fact we had to buy some rechargeable triple A batteries and a charger so that we can keep her charged up all the time!! Just to give you an idea she is an avid TV Watcher and she has the TV on 24/7. However if you want to get normal wear out of these they last about 10 to 12 hours a day. The sound for spoken language is pure and uninhibited. The sound for movies is clear and encapsulate you with emotion. These headphones were made to last they are built of solid material. They are not dainty. If you are keeping your wife or husband up at night watching TV I would suggest getting a pair of these they are fantastic and you will do yourself a favor by listening to awesome sound. It is unique when you can find a product as good as it touts! Happy listening.ðŸ˜‰
Title: Absolutely the best sound for wireless headphones on the market hands down!

Review Contents: The first RS 175 RF I purchased was to replace a Sony RF head phone...which worked right from the first time I plugged it in....this RS 175 RF did not.  It was sent out defective by Amazon's supplier...then a second one was sent, and that was defective.....third one as well!  That sucks!I thought at this price point, every headphone sent out should work as advertised....this company must have some serious issues w/ quality control.  I asked myself; "what would be the odds of 3 defective Sennheiser RS 175 RF sent out to the same customer?"  My guess?  Pretty long odds....maybe lottery odds!  If I was one of the head fellows in this company, and found out about this, my quality control people would end up looking for new jobs.So, the real question is why did it take me so long to do a review?  The forth pair arrived from the same vender who sent out the 3 defective ones....I was a little angry by that time....well, very angry.....but finally the forth pair sent worked!But by that time, I did not trust the Sennheiser brand any more.  It has been a year or more since that first defective pair came to my door, and the nightmare started.  Won't speculate how this could have happened to one customer....but the forth pair is still working as advertised.The four stars in the rating reflect that forth pair.  The first three defective ones don't even rate one star!I liked the Sony design a lot better than the Sennheiser's, but sadly Sony discontinued that part number...the Sony controls were not as complicated to use,the Sony controls were more user friendly....Sennheiser's are not.
Title: Hope the first pair works.....the first three I got did not!

Review Contents: Recently purchased two units so that I can enjoy movies late night without waking anyone up. Out of the box once I turned one on it didn't register any sound right away. However, upon further inspection I suspect that it was searching for a channel so don't be discouraged if it doesn't have any sound right away. It is well constructed and sturdy.Pros:-Nice sleek design.-Buttons easily accessible on the headset.-ComfortableCons:-uses AAA batteries( and even I don't think this is a huge issue)-can only charge one headset at a time unless you buy another receiver.-Max of two headsets per receiver.Comment Comment | Permalink
Title: Better than expected or could have asked for.

Review Contents: RS 175. The directions (Quick Guide) are very, very poor. Nowhere does it tell you to hold the ON button on the headset until the transmitter lights up. Nowhere does it give you any troubleshooting options. (I still cannot connect with digital audio.) A detailed product manual would be helpful. I cannot find one online.  I am using the plug-in jacks to the red and white audio output on the TV. The sound is tinny, not the rich sound without the headset. The headset buttons are difficult to find while on your head. I use 5GHz wifi to the TV so that is not a problem. The dual band router is in the basement one floor down. The range extender is in the laundry room about thirty feet away. No wifi interference at all even though everything else is on the 2.4GHz band because of the distance from the router.If I am doing something wrong I do not know it.
Title: Not the quality I expected

Review Contents: I recently bought a Samsung UHD TV for my living room. The surround system is right under the master bedroom making it impossible to listen at a reasonable volume with someone upstairs. In addition, my hearing loss makes it difficult to get all the dialog especially if there is a lot of background noise.These headphones solved both problems. I can now hear everything clearly and not bother anyone else.I purchased these refurbished and they arrived in a generic white box with a "Sennheizer QC" sticker inside. Included were a very thin optical cable and an analog connection cable. There was a quick reference guide that was fairly useless and a manual on CD which I did not take the time to review.The headphones are pretty straightforward to set up and get charging. Unfortunately they come uncharged and take a ridiculous 16 hours to reach full charge. Other reviewers have mentioned replacing the AAA batteries with other brands - something I will definitely try.As others have also mentioned, getting these to work required your source to be set to PCM (uncompressed) vs Dolby audio. I spent 20 minutes getting this cleared up. It would be helpful if this detail were prominent in the quick start guide.Sound quality is good - dialog is now clear. I am not blown away by the sound quality but that could be my ears. I am still playing with the bass boost and surround settings. So far, boost off and surround low seem to sound the best.I have worn these for two nights so far and they are comfortable enough to make it through a two hour movie without being annoying.
Title: Problem solver

Review Contents: Great sound.Less reception distance than my RS120 headphones, but still plenty far enough.I only have 3 complaints.  One, the shell is plasticky and although I can't hear it in the sound, if I touch them with my fingers they ring and echo enormously.  Even just eating something while wearing them, gives them this ringing echo.  Two, there should be better padding.  The unpadded center of the top where the charging contacts are rest on my bald head.  Seriously, makes for a nice sleek design visually, but it's not as comfortable as it should be.  Three, the level of passive sound isolation could be improved.  The rest of the world leaks in too much..though they don't seem to let much sound out - though I do listen at much lower volumes than I suspect most people do, usually.I find the bass boost and surround features usable, but could be better with a little ability to tailor it to my own desired sound.If the 3 items I mentioned above were fixed, these would not be 4 stars.  Or 5.  They'd be 6 stars!
Title: Likely the best choice, but could be improved!

Review Contents: Wow these are just super especially for the price! As my hearing has continued to fail over the last couple of years I have had a very hard time interpreting what is said on the TV causing the volume button to keep going higher and higher to the point of ridiculous. These wireless headsets are super easy to install (or move between TV's), easy to operate and the sound is awesome.  I even went back and watched some of the old shows that I had already watched and got a whole new perspective of what was said. They do not kill the volume on the TV so not an issue watching a show with your family. As a downer I will say the headphones are just a tad bulky but in trade for the clarity they provide this small issue  does not matter. Buy em you will love em
Title: Buy em you will Love em

Review Contents: Having had the rs170s for just over 4 years, we decided it was time to update given how much we use the 170s (everyday most of the time)--showing the wear but still functioning as well as day one.  I admit I have not always been delicate with my set especially during football season and it still works wonderfully, durable.first off, I love the sennheiser plastic loop inserted in the box in such a way that indicates if the box opened.  They did that with the 170s and it was there for both this box and the hdr175, optional headset.  I like receiving new stuff when I make a purchase.  I have had at times used stuff sent my way for new purchases.  Thank you amazon.com for sending me new items.a nice feature with the 175s is that no longer are we required to interact with the transmitter (base) to turn on the transmitter.  turning on the headsets will activate the base.  this aspect has worked every time tried so far.  I think sennheiser heeded the complaints and added this overdue capability.one minor issue I had was how the base does not initially indicate charged for a charged battery, i.e., the base takes some time, a couple of days, to work out a "sync" with the battery and its charge.  so, do not be alarmed, as I was and contacted support, if you charge a set the first day and it still indicates red, not charged.  the base will figure out, sorry, the sync between the charge and indicator.  I use two sets and now I have no issues charging and knowing when both are charged.there is one big downer and that is the wireless capability does not seem in any way improved over the rs170s; yes, that capability was/is great.  but, to my chagrin, in my house I have the exact same drops with the 175s I had with the 170s--due to obstacles, but not that far away.  it is disappointing given how wireless tech has changed over the recent years; I thought there would be some improvements with how robust the wireless tech is with this set.  NOTE:  the wireless connection is otherwise awesome when not challenging the set with too many obstacles.overall, I enjoy these headphones more than I enjoyed the 170s, so I consider these a great upgrade for the role as primarily for tv, movies/cable, and gaming.  the bass is more potent over the 170s, but not too much to be a problem.  we have the option to turn the bass off with the headphones.  NOTE:  if you turn the bass off for one set you turn it off for both sets.  same with the surround sound.  the surround sound is good, but I do not care so much about it too make much of a worthwhile comment.  it works and you have options therein.great product by sennheiser, again.  thank you.
Title: upgraded 170s to 175s, and satisfied

Review Contents: StrengthsSound quality really good for wireless, the best i have heard in fact for wireless. Better than a lot of wired too, to my ears these sound wonderful. I have a lot of headphones and am into audio as well. I think the sound would suit the tastes of 90% of people. For movies these kill, got me though when my daughter was in infant :) They extremely conformable with easily replaceable pads. i upgraded to the felt pads you can buy the 185 pads and they work fine. They are better than the stock ones that come with these for those of us that like the feel of felt.Simply fun to listen to. Close as you will get to a 2k home theater on a budget.Really just want to cut to the chase these are fun to listen to, and i feel they sound wonderful for movies. I can honestly say i don't think they could be any better for this usage.Also love having replaceable batteries. I have had this for a couple years now, and a buddy has has his a previous model for more than 10 years old (180) so i know they hold up fairly well.WeaknessesThey don't leak sound, but the sound isolation isn't the best as compared to some other over year phones i have tried. It isn't bad, just don't expect super isolation.The head band pad is not the best. Fake leather feels a little thin there too. The build is also not the most robust. I haven't had any issues but i am also really careful with my things. I wouldn't drop it. I'd be surprised if it could sustain a fall from 4-5 feet on a hard surface with out breaking.The price i paid for the full unit with the base station was 171. It is a buy at that price, no regrets, in fact i like the sound so much if i could find it for that price or lower i'd consider picking up a second done for work since i like it better than Bluetooth. while it isn't quite as flexible as bluetooth since you need this station, it performs better, and there are no hiccups with either lag, or bluetooth issues like jitter etc. In fact in all the years of owning this i have never had any issue audio or otherwise. I think 270 which i see from time to time is asking way  too much though they are good but let's not be crazy. The mark up on head phones is absurd. I'd wait for a sale. For what these do they are wonderful. If you want a pair of cans for your home theater system or computer, and don't need as much flexibility as bluetooth provides and have a scenario where audio performance is paramount, you'll totally love these.It really is significant in terms of quality it is a rich sound, with a nice sound stage and imaging which helps for movies and games.While not perfect if I am being picky, after years of owning this i am giving it 5 starts because i still use it, and it has served me really well, and i have been totally satisfied with my purchase. In fact i used this and my Bluetooth cans more than any of the corded ones i have these days, and i have some nice ones. This sound just about as good as some of my high end cabled head phones especially for things like movies. They are particularly tuned for that. My main gripes are I would love to see 1.) more isolation, 2.) more robust build quality 3.) this quality of sound on Bluetooth if it is possible. I mean i feel like i have to treat these things like fine china which they are :) I can honestly say these'd would by far be my go to head phones in all scenarios if i could get this sound quality on Bluetooth and not paying 500 dollars.Here is hoping. These have great imaging and are almost as good as open back headphones in sound stage. there is almost a surround sound nature to them, but they just sound great. If you want uncompromising high end sounds for your movies in a head phones these are the ones to get.
Title: One of my favorite electronic dad toys.

Review Contents: I bought this model due to the reviews, I just received these headset today 10/31/2016 and connected it to my my Sony 47 inches screen from the back using the digital audio output and they sound awesome. Made a few adjustment by using my menu from my Sony Led TV and once setting it up it just sounded awesome, the sound is incredible. Sounds like I'm in the TV show, I was watching the third Season of Flash. You can hear background noises of the computer back in Star Labs from where I could not hear them from my audio system in the past, the sound quality in these headset is excellent. I bought these as refurbished for $99.99 dollars with all the necessary accessories needed to set them up from out of the box to your TV. Just took a few minutes and test them with two episodes of Flash and I just fell in love with the sound quality. Now I'm going to fully recharge it since the batteries do not come fully charged. The good thing is once charged they last 24+ hours plus before you need to recharge them again. This are my first pair of wireless headset and since the recommendation from the reviews for Sennheiser is one of the most popular and reliable wireless headset. I can't wait to use them every night, believe me my wife loved them, after explaining to her what they can do, she said thank you Sennheiser. Its 1200 midnight on 11/1/2016 and my wife has not gotten up once. She is happily sleeping without any interruption of no TV noise. Like I said I love these headset they are awesome, sounds like your in the movies or better yet sounds your in the film. I sure if you buy one you will enjoy it too. Hope this review is helpful.Â Sennheiser RS 175 RF Wireless Headphone System
Title: My RS 175 Review

Review Contents: Life changers.  Need quiet and mobility in an apartment.I can't speak well to the music quality, but plenty of more knowledgeable people do that here.  I just have notes:-Digital infinitely better than analog-Real easy to hook up (almost forgot to turn them on, though)-Plain old A3 batteries work if the charge runs down on the rechargeables.-They're not intended to block sound, but they actually do better than my Bose QC35s.-Controls are easy to distinguish and are large.-Got them like new, and they're actually mint for about half off.  Even so, the quality is worth much more.-BIG plus is that they feel barely noticeable after a few minutes.  They're heavy, so I was concerned they might hurt.-Now to subscribe to Music Unlimited and audiobooks.
Title: life changers

Review Contents: Great sound. Nice padding. The only thing I don't like is more of a personal preference. I don't like how tightly they fit my head. It creates an almost airtight seal. It turns my head into a bass tube. I use these for watching TV while I eat. Not only do I get great sound from the TV, but also a greatly amplified internal crunching from the corn chips I'm chewing. The padding makes these really comfortable to wear, but after a few hours of watching I find I need a break from squeezing my head. I just wish there was a way to adjust this so people who like the tight fit can have it, but others who don't like that so much don't have to have it. Lengthening does little to alleviate the tight fit.
Title: Great sound, tight on the head

Review Contents: I am rewriting my review as my first attempt at getting the headset to perform was awful so I wrote about the less than awesome performance of this headset. BUT, the reason it wasn't performing correctly was my fault and not the quality of the headset. Basically the sound was dropping out often enough to make it impossible to listen to anything. I went through all of the troubleshooting steps without any success so I started over by resetting ALL of the settings on my TV. Hooked the RS-175 headset back up and it is NOW working great. I am a VERY happy camper!
Title: Outstanding Wireless Headset !!!

Review Contents: Good headphones.  My old sennheisers plugged into my satellite box with an RCA cable.  These went right into my Sony TV with the supplied optical cable. Easy peasy.  The volume control on the phones is not well designed.  You have to teach yourself to deal with it.  Very far from instinctive.  The phones are pretty heavy and a bit too confining.  They are not uncomfortable but they just 'bury' your ears inside the foam padding.  The sound is great.  I'm quite hearing impaired and can't get a lot of the dialog on TV programs without headphones.  These do the trick.  Can't say about the simulated surround sound.  Don't use it.Couple Months in:  The plastic below the actual ear muffs is coming apart.  I'm handling them gingerly but it won't last another year I'm sure.  Screw it.  I'll rebuild the ear muffs.  The hard plastic cover that twists off to get to the battery is solid.  I'll just jury rig new padding that will not be as confining anyway as the originals.  Still,  this is a shame.  I'm reducing my rating.
Title: Just OK For The Price but Clunky and poorly constructed

Review Contents: From my initial experience with these, they are absolutely phenomenal! The sound is crystal clear, and the bass is impressive, with 2 options to choose from; great bass, or extreme bass! The surround sound is a cool added bonus too, with two levels to choose from.Now the issues... First of all, I just want to say, the setup was super simple and awesome. I used the Digital Optical Audio Toslink Cable that was included in the box and connected it directly from my TV's Digital Optical Audio out to the Sennheiser dock for the best audio connection possible. I completed the setup process as per the quick start manual, and let it charge for half a day before trying them out. They worked great, and the sound exceeded all my expectations.Where the problem started was if I accidentally pushed the power button (while powered on) or even intentionally pushed it, like a typical button instead of holding it in to power it off, the audio would disappear yet the device would remain powered on. I know the manual says to hold it in for several seconds to power on or off, but sometimes you might accidentally push it, like when adjusting them on your head, or even when getting used to how they operate you might inadvertently push the button to power it off only to remember you must hold it in... I first thought that maybe it was a cool additional feature to mute the audio without powering them off, but pushing the button again did not bring the audio back, in fact no button would bring the audio back. The first time this happened I simply powered them off completely and then back on and I was good to go. However, twice since then I have accidentally pushed the button and lost audio, and powering it off and on wouldn't even bring it back. With my luck, this would usually happen just as I was beginning a movie or TV episode, and I was unable to get audio back for the duration of that use, having to resort to using my Bose sound system and watch the volume carefully.Each time I've encountered this issue I have ended up leaving the headset powered off on the charging dock, and the next day when I went to use them they worked just fine. I read completely through the operation manual several times trying to find anything on whether it was a mute function or used as something different aside from powering on or off, and I found absolutely nothing! In fact there was there was very little to practically nothing in all the papers included in the box on the operation of the device aside from how to set up the dock and connect to your TV, and insert the batteries in the headset and power it on. I figure they assume everything else is straight forward when it comes to buttons; bass, surround sound, and volume control. That being said, I would assume that the power button would be the same, not finding anything to say otherwise, its sole purpose is to power the headset on or off.I don't know why I have this problem, but I'm quite sure it isn't a dead battery because they are brand new, and two of the times it has happened I had just pulled them off of the charging dock with the green light indicating they were fully charged, and these are supposed to have quite an impressive battery life that I probably could never completely drain in a single day.. Other uses that I didn't bump the button or run into this problem, I would use them for up to six continuous hours, ruling out the battery as being the problem. All I can figure is that it could be a faulty pair??Aside from this one issue, if I am careful to not push the button until I am done using them for that setting, then I don't have any problems... And as I mentioned before, the sound is awesome!I have not yet reached out to Sennheiser for support, but I intend to when I get around to it. For now, this has been my experience with these, and I do intend to update my review if and when I resolve this problem.
Title: Absolutely amazing sound, with some interesting glitches that I haven't figured out yet!

Review Contents: My husband wears hearing aids and it was hard to understand the TV. When closed captioning disappeared from our TV, I researched headphones to aid his TV viewing pleasure. We did get closed captioning back after getting a new DVR receiver from DirecTV (just in case someone else has this problem). However, the Sennheiser wireless headphones work wonderfully.  They have increased my husband's TV viewing pleasure 95%. We still use closed captioning for those few words neither of us can quite catch.  Thank you for a great product.
Title: FANTASTIC PRODUCT

Review Contents: Excellent headphones, if you have an optical digital (toslink) input on your TV or the intended connection device. First off, these 175s work great when connected to an optical digital device like a high end HDTV. The sound is crisp and clear, the surround sound at all 3 levels is superb and the extra bass boost is awesome. It creates a new experience as I heard sounds, mostly background sounds, that I never heard before. Movies like Alien, Event Horizon, Leviathan, Friday the 13th and Halloween really come alive. The experience is overwhelming.If you plan on using these with the analog input, the sound suffers due to the inadequacy of the drivers. For me, sound ducks under - meaning the device automatically turns the volume down when it receives a sound it thinks is too loud such as an explosion or gun shot in a movie. After that, it's hard to hear much of anything. With a few consecutive explosions it will continue to duck under until I only hear a faint whisper.I bought these with the intention of proofing recordings. The fit is good for over the ear and the quality is fantastic. For the most part they works, but keeps ducking under. To correct this, I have to turn them off and than back on. It has gotten to the point where I find them hard to use, but can live with it. I keep the volume low and that seems to help, but if a cymbal or bass kick is a tad too loud - it ducks under. Since I was not able to find a solution to this problem, I now just mostly use them for TV and practicing on my guitar. It still ducks under now and then, but I hope to find a solution as the sound the produce is incredible.I do like the Digital/Analog switch on the back. I can keep my TV and Guitar amp both hooked up all the time. No need to fiddle with any wires. With a simple flip of the switch, I can watch the latest horror flick or play my guitar - all with disturbing others. I also like that I can control the volume, surround sound and bass from either the base unit or the head phones. When proofing recordings I don't use any surround sound, but I noticed if I go from normal mode to SURR2 it sounds really close to what I would expect from a mastered recording. They really work great for proofing, I just hope I can find a solution to my problem.All in all, these are great if you have a digital input, but the analog needs some work. The sound is exhilarating - just ask my friend George.
Title: Great Digital Input, So-So Analog Input...

Review Contents: Update: 3/25/2018. I believe long term reviews can be a great help to people, this is about a year and a half later. I have had zero issues with the headphones since my purchase. The only thing I changed was the batteries, I put a different brand (energizer) for the rechargeables. No issues with build quality at all, sound is still great and they're still  comfortable to this day.First, I'm impressed with the range. Have a somewhat large apartment and no issues with it in any room. Actually makes cleaning less of a chore as I can just wear this and listen to the news or music if I connect the stand to my phone.COMFORT. Very comfortable, but may feel weird to you at first. Give it a couple days. I have a big head and the clamping on my head isn't bad at all for me personally (I wear a Large/XL Bern helmet when snowboarding) it's a non issue. The earcups are quite large which I like. No part of my ear touches the sides of the earcups. Sure the leatherette gets somewhat warm but I've worn these for 6 hours straight without a problem. If they get too warm for you there's also the velour pads that you can buy here on Amazon but they'll likely isolate sound a little less.DESIGN: A little bulky but not a problem as you won't be going out and about with this like you would regular headphones. If you're just wearing them in the apartment or house, who cares what you look like. The packaging was somewhat comical. Box within a box within a plastic box (then little plastic bags in the box) but they arrived undamaged which was the important part. No big deal.SETUP: Extremely easy. I don't think I can post the link but search on Youtube for Sennheiser RS 175 and there's a setup guide that's clear and easy to understand. Batteries are included but will need charged. Charging time is no issue, I put them on the charger when I go to bed and by morning they're ready to go.SOUND: Very clear, very clean sound. The bass boost isn't overpowering at all. The surround sound option is obviously not a true surround, as in having speakers set up in certain areas of your living room but it's not bad for a set of headphones. I think it's going to be personal preference if you want the surround on or not but personally I also keep the bass boost on as well as it gives more of a movie feel to the sound.
Title: Details inside!

Review Contents: These headphones were relatively easy to hook up.  I had an older Sony pair that were beginning to skip quite a bit.  These are radio frequency not blue tooth and it seems to make a difference.  The quality of the sound is excellent.  I can understand every word.  Would highly recommend.
Title: These headphones were relatively easy to hook up

Review Contents: This was a joint gift to my husband from my two sons and me. My husband is hard of hearing, but very resistant to doing ... well, anything ... about it. He's previously rejected the idea of headphones because he doesn't want the discomfort, and also doesn't want to be "tied" to the TV with a cord. My younger son, who is a gamer, picked these out for us to give my husband for Christmas, and I have to say, he LOVES them. I'm pretty amazed. Now my only problem will be getting him to take them off ....
Title: I'm pretty amazed. Now my only problem will be getting ...

Review Contents: The headphone is a great for watching movies, music, videos, and for walking around the house without worrying about cables.The main problem with these headphones is that if you have it near a router or anything that might disrupt the signal, whatever you are listening to will cut off regularly. This is the only thing. Since i have everyone on one desk, i had to figure out a way to keep the base away from my router. The sound quality is awesome â€”give or take the little surround sound features and the bass boost that are a little gimmickyâ€”and the comfort is goodâ€”although like many closed back headphones, it can get very hot after long periods of use.Overall, make sure you put the base away from your router or your experience will suck.
Title: Address the connection warnings and you will love these

Review Contents: The range is stated to be up to 100 meters but walls and floors reduce that significantly. To get a very rough idea of the range to expect in a typical wood frame house Iâ€™ve come up with the following guide; heavy metal objects such as boilers in line of sight reduce the range even further:Same floor- range is three rooms away or about 20 meters (60 feet)One floor above/below- range is two rooms away from the room directly under the transmitter, or about 10 meters (30 feet)Through one exterior wall- range is about 45 feet (15 meters) facing away from the transmitter, 30 feet (10 meters) when facing it.Your range will vary from mine based on many factors.I have not found the â€œsurround soundâ€ settings helpful but sometimes the Bass boost is nice to use, and the on headset volume controls are wonderful!A few words about digital wireless audio: there isnâ€™t any static or fading of volume over distance so you wonâ€™t constantly have to adjust volume as you change distance from the transmitter. The down side is either you get a good static free signal or nothing, as the unit goes in and out of range suddenly and without any clicks or hiss.
Title: Usable Range Estimate

Review Contents: I am not an audiophile but I can tell the difference between a good headphone and a not so good one. I got this to watch movies (and I like action movies:) at night when kids are in bed. I was not very happy at the idea of giving up my 5.1 audio system for this headphone. While it doesn't give you the same experience as you would have from a 5.1 system, it does a great job of delivering crisp sound and the surround sound option does make a big difference. I like it.
Title: ... audiophile but I can tell the difference between a good headphone and a not so good one

Review Contents: The first unit, according to Sennheiser, was not new, it was a refurbished unit sold as new and was defective. The second unit was new but could not be heard very far away; in fact an old Sennheiser tr140 could be hear further away. Not recommended and surprise I was sent a refurbished unit.
Title: 1st unit refurbished and defective, second unit not as good as an older model

Review Contents: You are not losing your hearing, some folks are just too precious for 21st century life.You know who I am talking about.Great for late night listening or living with sensitive types with control issues who demand quiet media volume.Sound not entirely audiophile but good enough for TV viewing and listening while you work.Very large sounds like that drumbeat on the GOT theme seem to overwhelm the amp and results in annoying jarring dropouts.Wishing the volume was adjustable in an old fashioned analog style infinite range instead of large push button steps that are sometime too loud or too soft. Same for that bass boost on-off only which can quickly become painful as the soundtrack changes.
Title: Great for late night listening or living with sensitive types with control issues who demand quiet media volume.

Review Contents: Had a really old version of from Sennheiser that worked for 12 years.  Had hard time trying to pick a replacement.  Treated myself to these as a Christmas gift. Worked great for the first 45 days now there is an issue with the included batteries draining really fast.  I removed and charge in a regular battery charger.  Reinstalled and it drained again in about an hour.  Replaced factory batteries with new Energizer rechargeable batteries.  Same results.  Something has changed to cause the batteries to drain at a much higher rate.  For the first month the battery life was impressive, and never had an issue with running out even after 5 hours of use.  Also when you place it back onto the cradle to charge the Red light never goes to Green to indicate that it is charged.  The light stays Red even when the other battery charger thinks they have a full charge.  Use the charger and batteries for other devices with no issues.  So my choice is to go thru the issues with Warranty Work, or switch to regular batteries to try and bypass the issue.  I expected more from this manufacture.  The $180 I paid is not super expensive, but not inexpensive either.Contacted the Manufacture via their website.  I was issued a prepaid return label for replacement within a day or two.  Somewhat new replacement arrived about 5 days later.  That was 2 weeks ago and new unit is fine.  Time will tell.  I am impressed with the service, which was prompt, and correct.
Title: Battery / Charge Issues

Review Contents: I have had these headphones for about nine months now, and use them daily.  I bought them to hear the TV set better.  The new wide screen tvs have terrible sound systems.  I bought a set of external speakers for the tv, and it only helped a little.  These have helped a lot.  I debated and debated on which set to buy.  I read everything I could find, and it boiled down to two brands, Sennheiser being one of them.  I couldn't decide on which pair to buy.  I think for hearing problems the most expensive set is the best, but I didn't want to spend that much.  Most of the sound options on these different sets improve bass quality, which doesn't help for hearing loss.  I rarely use the sound effects on these.  I rely on the good sound that they produce.  With good clear sound I can understand much better what is being said on the tv programs.  If the sound is bad.  The characters are speaking in a heavy accent, there is a bunch of back ground music nothing is going to help.  There is absolutely no static, distortion, or weak signal with these.  Just good sound.  I do use the sound effects with a roaring action movie with lots of music, but that is all.  These are not a cure all if you have hearing loss, but they do help a lot.  TV shows that I have had trouble with in the past understanding what they say are now enjoyable.  A big plus with these are watching TV while my wife is asleep.  I can watch in the middle of the night without disturbing her.  The buttons are no problem either.  Once you get used to them they are easy to use while the headset is on your head.
