But frankly, I could not tell much difference, if any, between the regular headphone jack and the optical.  They headphones could certainly use a little more bass.  For voice, they are superb and the surround function works very well.
Title: Great headphones, but

Review Contents: these headphones lasted about 5 months, sometimes working sometimes not until they died completely. DO NOT WASTE YOUR MONEY!!!!!
Title: Expensive JUNK

Review Contents: Best sound in any headphone I have tried (wired or wireless). Very easy to charge on the base and has multiple ways to hook up to an audio source (I am using the optical audio out of my TV). Bass is great for music or movies as well as the surround sound effects. I had an older model Sennheiser wireless headphones prior to these and they have lasted me years, but the bass was non-existent or distorted and hooking up to my TV required a separate audio converter. I had these on my wish list on Amazon for a long time and finally had my wife get them for Christmas and the price had come down a lot. Believe me you won't be disappointed with these headphones.
Title: Phenomenal

Review Contents: I have had hearing problems for several years now and use headphones to watch TV. When my ihip set started going bad my wife said time to order another set. I chose Sennheiser RS 175, and so far am well satisfied. They hold a charge for my TV viewing throughout the day, they are comfortable, and when I have these on they cut out all other noise. My wife is not happy with them, because now she has to wave her arms, or get up and tap me on the shoulder to get my attention. They are easy to connect to TV, I use them at home and take them with us in the RV. If you need a set of headphones I recommend these.
Title: Sennheiser RS 175 "Get er Done"

Review Contents: Bought these for my grand dad for christmas. I hooked them up to test and worked flawlessly. Something that is easy to hook up and can have sound through the headset and speaker.  Worth the money compared to the lower version. 165 I think was the one I was looking at. This one has the audio in that worked.
Title: Wireless is amazing

Review Contents: I bought these to better understand movie and TV dialog that varies from whispers to shouting without continually adjusting the volume. Problem solved. Excellent clarity and stereo separation. The headphones are bulky and heavy. Bothers my ears after a few hours of use. The wireless signal tends to drop in and out while walking through the house. They work fine while sitting still watching TV. Not so good listening to music while moving around the house doing daily chores.
Title: Improves dialog clearity

Review Contents: I've had the Sennheiser RS 175 headphones for a month now. It is a great product and I only have one nit pick: The volume control has too wide of a granularity for me. One click minus and too soft, one click plus and too loud. This varies quite a bit with which surround mode you select. Regarding the surround modes and bass boost; I partially agree with the reviewers who say these are useless features. On new sound sources with high quality 5.1 sound these modes are detractors. But on old stuff, old movies, and especially old music videos, these modes are really great. You can make the old stuff sound a lot more full and open up the sound stage. I've had no problems with comfort, batteries, range, interference, or distortion.
Title: It is a great product and I only have one nit pick

Review Contents: This was a Christmas present and after 3 months he still loves them! THEY ARE SOUND PROOF to noises in the room. So if I want his attention I have to yell, but this is to be expected from the closed (I think this is what they call them)earphones -meaning not able to hear room noises and thats the way he likes it!
Title: This was a Christmas present and after 3 months he ...

Review Contents: Talk about a massive disappointment.  Absolutely terrible in terms of volume level.  For $240 I thought you'd be able to turn these up to at least an acceptable level of sound.  I had a 10 year old pair of Sony headphones that I paid $90 for and were wonderful.  What's up with the lack of volume on these things?  Can barely hear the sound, (and yes I do have them turned up all the way).
Title: Talk about a massive disappointment. Absolutely terrible in terms of volume level

Review Contents: Much sturdier (more durable), more comfortable and blocks extraneous noise better than my two prior purchases of http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00HWFPJKCWorks with standard or rechargeable AAA batteries. Handy included charging stand is easier to use than taking Silent Safari headphones with their built-in battery to a USB port on PC to recharge. Sound from TV transmits in a ghz range that does not conflict with other wireless device controls on mhz range, as did Silent Safari. Wireless headphones are ideal for hearing-impaired, with clear reception even with summertime fans blowing.
Title: Have TV at normal volume (or muted) for others, but hear clearly with headphones!

Review Contents: Works well but range is relatively short.  Wish they made a 900 MHz version for better range--this works on 2.4GHz which can be crowded due to WiFi, cordless phones, etc.
Title: Wish they made a 900 MHz version for better range--this works on 2

Review Contents: We have used this wireless headphone system with our new computer in the bedroom for over 6 months. At night, my wife watches TV while I read. The system works perfectly By charging the headphones during the day, they have never run out of power at night, even if my wife has trouble sleeping and uses them most of the night. I recommend them highly.
Title: Excellent

Review Contents: works amazingly. I use it primarily when gaming and the wireless functionality is really nice. The furthest I have been able to push it was about four rooms (each with fairly thick walls between them) so i have no complaints there. The only gripe I have is that the headband can get a bit uncomfortable after a few hours (also, the cups squeeze my glasses into my head which is probably just my glasses). Great product nonetheless and would recommend to others
Title: Great product, but uncomfortable after long sessions

Review Contents: I have owned several brands and types of headphones and these are by far the best I have ever had. The sound is crisp and very understandable. I have a hearing problem so headphones are a must for me to watch tv and hear it. I have now found the perfect set of headphones. I would recommend these phones to anybody needing headphones.
Title: Fantastic Sound!

Review Contents: Work well but too tight around the ears.  Also the volume controls are not ideally located ergonomically and hard to find by feel..
Title: Work well but too tight around the ears. Also ...

Review Contents: Fantastic beyond belief. I could hear things I never could hear before. It is so good I bought a set for both of my kids and they love it also. Forget going to the movies, why put up with idiots making noise and kicking your seat when you can have the best of everything at home.I have owned several Sennheiser headphones over the years and this is light years better than any other set they have ever put out. The base goes so low it shakes your lungs and makes your think it is breathing for you. The highs are so clear you can literally hear a pin drop. And they are so quite that when there is no sound in the movie, you will think they shut off, no buzzing, no pops, no sound at all, dead silence. Buy a set, you only live once.My set was refurbished, and other than the white box, were like new. I use them with a Sony tv, connected with an optical cable. They are big enough to fit over your ears, and they block out most outside noise so you can hear what is going on in the presentation. The volume controls are easy to find and use, and step seamlessly up or down.
Title: The best I have ever used.

Review Contents: I loved this unit.  Easy to hook up and looks great too.  Unfortunately l could not get it to work through no fault of the unit, my Panasonic tv would not allow me to make the necessary audio output change.  The company was very nice to work with as they took the unit back with no hassle even though it was no fault of theirs.
Title: great unit...I wish I could have used it

Review Contents: What can I say? The quality and sound of this headphone is amazing. Not to mention my wife is also very satisfied with this because I don't have to blast my TV!
Title: Wifey is stoked! And so am I.

Review Contents: I bought these to drown out loud neighbors without tethering myself to my computer. Range is acceptable... I haven't had any issues even while in an adjacent room, but beyond that it might get a bit sketchy. Supposedly the range is very good if there is line of sight between the transmitter and the headset, but I am quite pleased how well it performs even as I walk around different rooms in my apartment.Sound quality is great, though I admittedly am not terribly discriminating. Being able to control the volume from the headset is awesome. I haven't tested the battery life, but I use these comfortably for hours every day without issue.
Title: Great sound, good range, comfortable

Review Contents: I upgraded from my previous version of this product.  The new design is well thought out and easy to use.  The sound quality is exactly what I expect from Sennheiser.  Comfortable to wear for long periods.  I upgraded the batteries to a little more amp hour rating just as I had done on my previous version and yes my previous version is still working.  I took that set into work so I can have a cord free environment there as I listen to music while I work.  All in all a great product line.
Title: Upgraded to a newer version

Review Contents: So far I am pleased with my purchase.  Decent sound for TV shows, movies and casual music listening and the same goes for comfort but I found myself taking them off for a few minutes every hour or so to let my ears breath.
Title: So far, so good!

Review Contents: Quality set. Family happy that they can work without hearing TV.  Sound excellent, long range into next room for mobility. Just what we were searching for, other less expensive models can't compare. Worth it's cost. No disappointments here.
Title: Quality Excellent, Designed Well.

Review Contents: Works great!!  Much more comfortable that similar headphones. I ordered a second pair for different TV in bedroom.
Title: Works great

Review Contents: I am having trouble plugging in the digital cable. It does not want to stay and is too small to see what I must do. The headphones work great using the analog plug. I am not disturbing my wife with the T sounds.
Title: Great Tool

Review Contents: I got this for my hard of hearing friend that comes over and turns my TV volume way up.  I was worried that we were all going to loose our hearing, including my 3 yr old grandson!  So far it has been working fine.  My friend can hear the TV.and we do not  not have to keep turning down the volume when he leaves the room!
Title: So far it has been working fine. My friend can hear the TV

Review Contents: wow ! sound amazing. Tested the battery life -  after full charge i turned them on and if i wasnt using them i left the tv going and the headphones running for 14 hours. Decided i dont need to know how long the batteries will last i cant see myself using them for 14 hours straight but good to know it shouldnt be an issue if I do =)
Title: Impressive !!

Review Contents: Bass- freaking amazing, especially with bass booster 9/10Clarity- amazingTreble- 9/10Comfort- 9/10
Title: Best Headphones ever!

Review Contents: Yes, GET THESE, if you are shopping for wireless headphones for your gaming, TV or whatever. Perfect, absolutely perfect, in every way. Massive 2015 upgrade of already great RS 170 models, that I also used to own.1. Comfort level is excellent. Cushions are foamy and soft. The band is very "loose" and breaks in quickly to adjust for head sizes. Weight is less than heavy,  I'd say they're medium, but definitely not light. Previous RS 170 model was actually light, these aren't.2. VOLUME - YEEES, max volume here is blasting, to the point of being painful. The volume buttons on the right headphone are easily located by touch, they have little ridges on them. Bass and Surround buttons on the headphones themselves are pretty useless, and do sometimes get in the way, when trying to change volume. They should definitely get rid of them in the next iteration.3. The base station has dim lights and nothing is blinking, so it's just nicey barely visible solid green lights that don't bother or annoy. Station looks pretty and modern too, totally in the right place on your desktop or shelve.4. Input switch located on the back is just awesome. Simple little tumbler, nothing silly-fancy like the 10 step process on SteelSeries H.5. Sound quality is superb. Added bass option is also great, I am running it "On" right now, but I do turn it off sometimes, if I feel like it. I don't use the surround, but whatever, someone might like it, the option is there.6. Recharging process is as simple as can be. Take your headphones, and place them on the station overnight. That is it, you are done.7,8,9...Quality, quality product guys and gals. Product has definitely evolved over time after serious customer feedback.Just buy em! You'll thank me later )))
Title: Totally GET THESE! German Engineering at its Finest

Review Contents: I have had a pair of Sennheiser RS 120 for several years and like them a lot but thought to upgrade to digital.  Very sorry I wasted my money. The RS 175 sound cuts out every so often, especially if you are moving about.  The RS 175 headset is much heavier and very uncomfortable.  The ear pads are very tight, I suppose to block out other surrounding noise.  The pad makes you feed sweaty even though room temp is normal.  Subsequently I am still using my old RS 120 Headphone and the RS 175 is sitting on charger as a backup.
Title: Sound cuts out.

Review Contents: These headphones are fantastic. I've had them for a day and they're just so wonderful.Bass response is incredible, you can feel the drivers vibrate and shake your head without distorting too much. The bass boost option works great if your music source is good enough. The surround sound option works depending on what your audio source is too as well.For $250 you can't go wrong with Sennheiser.
Title: You can never go wrong with Sennheiser

The other sets are either in other rooms or a vacation home.......The other sets were great, but the RS 175 RF are amazing! They cup over your ears and not on them as before...You'll not be sorry if you purchase the RS 175.
Title: Sound is A M A Z I N G -

Review Contents: Setup Update 2/1/17: I found the ear cups on the Sennheiser RS175 RF 's to be a touch shallow (I have large ears so no points deducted- not Sennheiser's fault) so I replaced them withÂ Brainwavz HM5 Velor Memory Foam Replacements Earpads for Over The Ear Headphones. Now I can say that this set of headphones is more or less perfect for me. I am also usingÂ rolls MX51S Mini Mix II 2 1/4 & 3 RCA MixerÂ to mix audio into the headset. I typically use it to listen to Podcasts while also playing video games (PS4). This set up rocks!!!Head phones still working great. These are awesome. They sound great. Bass boost is fairly booming. The surround sound function is not great- too echoing, but I don't care about that feature. They felt a little tight the first time I put them on, but they have yet to really fatigue me head/ears. Also I have fairly large ears and the cups fit around them very well.Finally I was concerned that the 2.4ghz that the headphones use would mess with my wifi. So far so good. No loss us strength/speed.
Title: Everything I wanted.

Review Contents: I use these phones with to watch tv movies.  I am hard of hearing, and even with hearing aids, I cannot understand all of the dialogue.  I take out the ha's and use the phones, which help a lot.  If you have an audio amplifier or a set without RCA jacks, you may have to do research on hookin g up these cans. With these headphones I still experience the theater sound and I have immediate control over volume. They are fun to use. Sounds are crystal clear.

Title: Unbelievable quality, wonderful experience!

Review Contents: Overall, I am very pleased with these headphones though there are some short comings, but first the good stuff. I'd like to think of myself as an audiophile but my hearing isn't good enough to actually make that claim.  That said, sound quality and range are quite good according to my expectations.  I enjoy the enhanced bass and the virtual surround.  Now, the less than perfect.  The volume +/-, bass and surround controls are grouped in a tight circle on the right ear piece and are nearly indistinct from each other making adjustments hit or miss.  he headphones don't drop onto the charging cradle  as easily as my other Sennheiser rechargeables do.
Title: I am very pleased with these headphones though there are some short comings

Review Contents: They are very comfortable and the wireless works very well, Never experienced any disconnecting or distortion. Battery life is good on them as I can use them for gaming all day. Set up was very seemless and sound quality is alright, Not as good as some other sennheiser headphones but they're still pretty good.
Title: They are very comfortable and the wireless works very well

Review Contents: I have  been using the RS140 over ear and my wife the RS120 on ear headsets. The missus complained about ambient noise and wanted RS140s like mine, but they don't make them anymore. Even though the 140s keep out much ambient noise, mine were sounding quite muddy. I also wear hearing aids under the ear cushions which helps a bit, Even with that setup I have a hard time with the dialogue. Seems like they are always mumbling.So I was hunting for some over ear headsets for the wife and came upon these. I would guess the RS170s are much the same, except they have no digital optical. I opted for these RS175s so I could go with digital sound vs. analogue. I received the phones yesterday (I purchased the extra phone for myself). Swapped the batteries from the old headsets as they were charged up and ready to go. Easy to hook up, just plug in the optical cord and turn everything on.I was shocked, shocked I say with the fidelity of these headsets. I could understand every word of the programs we were watching. And that's with no hearing aids :o)Pros;AAA batteries are easy to replace and can be supplemented by standard batteries if the rechargeable batteries go dead.Headsets are quite comfortable, but of course there is always a bit of body heat built up inside the ear cushions over time.Volume and special effects are easy to control with fairly large buttons on the headset.Sound is crisp and clear, even if the bass is pumped up - 3 choices on the bass.This is a very handsome piece of gear.Cons:My major beef is that even though the base unit will work with two (max) headsets, I can only charge one at a time and according to the manual, it takes 8 hours for a full charge. I purchased the HDR175 (headset only) so we could both enjoy this upgrade. Sennheiser does not make a charge only cradle for this additional headset so I have to remember to switch headsets on the cradle for charging. I can also remove the batteries and place them in my old headset for a recharge. Since the main reason, as I see it, for purchasing an additional headset is so that two people can use this at the same time, doesn't it make sense to make available a charger for the second headset? Maybe even include one with the headset.  I give them two lousy little measly stars on this issue.

Title: Wonderful Headphones for hard of hearing.

Review Contents: Pros:============+ They sound decent, which of course is the most important thing.+ They seem to run a long time on a charge; I use them a lot and they get thru the day fine, then recharge overnight.+ Batteries are easily replaceable, so when they die, the headphones don't become useless junk. HUGE plus here. I hate planned / careless obsolescence, as we see in typical smartphones with their [self-censored] non-replaceable batteries.+ They're comfortable. A little heavy, batteries and all that, but I don't mind the weight.+ The range is outstanding. No noise.+ Good looking setup.Cons:============- There's some kind of automatic volume compensation going on. I have music set up to be quiet, kind of as a background. I set the volume on the phones where I want it. Then, the computer announces something to me at normal volume, which is a good bit louder than the music, which is exactly what I want and intended. But the headphones DROP the volume so that the announcement is at the volume I set the music to, and then when the announcement is over, the music is WAY too quiet. This is [self-censored] annoying as [self-censored]. I took two stars off for this.- The initial charge time is also annoying, but it's only once, so I can grin and bear it on that one, no points off, but hey. Definitely annoying once. You just bought them, you'd like to use them. Can't really do that, according to the docs, or you compromise the battery life. They'll be sitting on the stand for the first day you own them.- Turning them on requires holding the power switch on the headphones for a while. I don't see why. It's a minor nit, no points off, but... I just don't see why. It's a pretty positive switch: I should be able to press it, and it should just work.- A little bit of background hiss. I could do without this, but it's only obvious when there is no audio coming through. So... meh.Don't cares:============? Bass "enhancement": no thanks, leave my audio alone - I want to hear it as it is.? Surround: no thanks, leave my audio alone - I want to hear it as it is.

Title: Amazon's price was good. Shopped around in electronic stores where sold and ...

Review Contents: I bought these to replace a set of Sony MDR-HW700DS wireless surround sound headphones that started cutting out frequently, and then failed altogether. Unlike the RS 175 RF, the Sony model had true surround sound decoding and used psychological acoustics to create a surprisingly realistic surround sound experience. They were substantially more comfortable to wear with much thicker ear cups, and they used lithium ion batteries, which are lighter in weight and have no memory efffect. On the other hand, they listed for $400 with a street cost of $300, had a more limited range than the RS 175 RF and they cut out quite often, just from turning your head. Unfortunately Sony has done little to address their problems and their current offerings are mostly available only as Japanese imports. That is why I decided to switch to Sennheiser.The Sennheiser RS 175 RF is an excellent product, but when compared to the more expensive Sony's the differences are evident. For one thing, Sennheiser only offers simulated surround sound, which is not the same thing. With the Sony's, if a sound came from behind you, it really sounded like it was coming from behind you. That's the advantage of a true surround sound decoder. With the Senn's, even if you use the optical digital input, it will not accept a 5.1 surround sound signal. You have to set the output of your TV or video receiver to output stereo PCM for the Senn's to work. The Senn's use NiMH batteries, which have a memory effect, and then compound the problem with a charging stand that is guaranteed to make it worse if used as intended. The one saving grace is that the batteries are NiMH AAA batteries, making it easy and inexpensive to replace them, or to substitute alkaline batteries in a pinch. The ear cups are rather thin and uncomfortable with prolonged use.I would have paid more for a more premium product, but this is the best wireless headphone series that Sennheiser has to offer. Of course Sennheiser also offers the RS 185 RF, intended more for listening to music, and the RS 195 RF, which has multiple signal conditioning options, but even as expensive as the 195s are, they do not offer any surround sound options, they still use NiMH batteries, and they still use the same uncomfortable ear cups. Sennheiser also offers the Momentum 2 Wireless bluetooth headphones, which I own as well, and although they are a hundred time more comfortable to wear and use lithium ion batteries, the sound isn't as good, even with low latency AptX encoding. The Momentums may be the best bluetooth headphones out there in multiple reviews, and they do have active noise cancellation, but in direct side-by-side comparisons, there is no comparison. The RS 175 RFs sound like wired headphones. The only way the Momentums best the RS 175 RFs is when using a wired connection, which is why I'm keeping the 175s.In terms of range, the RS 175 RFs are a bit disappointing. I can get only perhaps 10% farther than I do with a bluetooth connection, but then I live in a large NYC apartment building with more than 20 WiFi networks in range. Overall, the Sennheiser RS 175 RF is an excellent wireless headphone system, but it's not outstanding. I would gladly pay more for a premium model with true surround sound decoding and a headphone more in line with the Momentum line, with lithium batteries, plush ear cups and better sound quality.
Title: Excellent and perhaps the best wireless headphones for cinema, but could have been so much better

Review Contents: I purchased the Sennheiser RS175 RF for a Christmas present for myself and I am totally impressed with the quality of the phones.  The sound quality is simply unbelievable. I am a somewhat hearing impaired as a result of many years in the Navy, but my old 76 year old ears have now come back to life. I use the ear phones with my TV, and I am hearing sounds I never knew where there.  I'm hooked.
Title: I purchased the Sennheiser RS175 RF for a Christmas present ...

Review Contents: I upgraded from the TR 120 that just finally wore out after several years. I'm hard of hearing (HOH) and wear hearing aids when with other people, but they are just annoying when watching TV. The Sennheiser 120's were vital in helping me hear what people said on TV shows and movies, especially... forgive me, I'm from Brooklyn... shows from England and Scotland. My wife and I used to have to watch those shows with subtitles! But the Sennheiser 120's fixed that. So they wore out. I needed to replace or upgrade. So I upgraded way up! Sure, much more costly than the Sennheiser 120's, but from the first minute with the Sennheiser RS 175's I could tell it was worth every penny. As with the 120's, I could hear what people were saying, but I had no idea that I was missing so much richness in background audio. It is a delight to hear sound in depth, not just surround sound, but real depth.My general setting so far is no bass and no surround. With movies I've been kicking in the surround on the lower setting, maybe some bass, usually not. These are digital so I'm not worried about the tuning wheel or volume wheel wearing out as they did on the Sennheiser 120's, 'cause the 175's don't have wheels but button areas that you press.My recommendation -- While I have no experience or expertise in headsets, my suggestion is that if you're HOH or aging and starting to lose the edge in what people are saying on TV, instead of kicking the TV volume up, invest in a pair of these RS 175's and give yourself a rare treat.By the way... my hearing aids were $6,000. The Sennheiser RS 175's with tax were about $300.
Title: Audio Challenged? These are an outstanding value for the Hard of Hearing

Review Contents: good quality sound, doesn't break up. My Dad's hard of hearing, so I bought them so I don't have to hear his TV.  Now if I could just get him to wear them more often!  He has commented that the sound is good and he hears well with them.
Title: good quality

Review Contents: This is my second review of the Sennheiser RS 175 wireless headphones. A previous review gave them 2 Stars, primarily due to poor product support. This time around, they get a 5 STAR rating. The sound quality is just great, especially for movies where the dialogue may be difficult to hear. For those who are hearing impaired, these headphones are a superb solution.I must say, however, that getting them set up can be a challenge if you have a sound system, or even a smart TV. The use of the optical connection is simple, but you next have to adjust the "sound settings" in your menu devoted to "Sound." I actually had to make two adjustments to move from "Bit Rate" to "PCM" on my system. Then, make sure that your "TV Speakers" are turned to "on."I ordered the accessory headphone set for my wife. It is a duplicate of the original RS 175 headphone set in all respects. The Sennheiser transmitter supports and will handle 2 headset without loss of signal or sound quality to either head set.I recommend this product without reservation, especially for those who are able to adjust their TV sound settings without getting lost. If that is not the case, then roll the dice with tech support.

The new one is MUCH better in almost every regard bar one I'll cover a little later;Major Highlights Include:1) Digital Connection, no more issues with analog interference which used to annoy me (Workaround was to turn source volume up high and headphone volume down.2) Turns off when not being used. Detects Audio and when it hasn't had music/sound played, and turns off.3) Turns on from the headset, saving a visit to the base station, which was required on the RS175's!4) Great Sound Quality. Sound stage is the biggest I've ever heard of any headphones.Downsides:1) It's quite tight on your head, which I find a little annoying. It's not massively horrible, but noticeable.

Review Contents: I spend a lot of time in "my man cave" working with woodworking machinery.I needed something to enjoy listening to my big screen TV/radio which would be drowned out when the furnace kicked on or the well pump was running or running my saw and other equipment.I also needed some hearing protection when running machinery, if not as good as my normal ear protection then at least some kind of protection. Note that these are not advertised nor any claims made for decibel reduction or hearing protection but they seem to work that way.Also i was annoying my wife when i put the TV on a high volume and blasted the upstairs, then in order to stop annoying anyone i would have to stop what i was doing to turn the volume down when the noise stoped or a commercial came on.The hardest part was waiting to use these as they charged up for 16 hours. So the first thing you should do is plug them in to charge.The sound was better than the TV alone, you can adjust bass and treble. Plus once you set it, it remembers what the settings were. I had the volume down low and when the furnace kicked on i could hear just fine even standing next to the noise. I got a break as these were "open box" and the only thing missing were the instructions. Those were found quite easily on the web.I have a full acre lot and i walked some distance away from the house to see how far i could get and still have reception.I got about 150 feet and they cut out, keep in mind the doors and windows were shut as its winter! i have a feeling that if i had the window open i would be able to listen to music while mowing the lawn. The headset was good quality, if you take reasonable care of these they should last, some people are rougher on equipment than others but i tend to be careful with my stuff.Overall I'm quite pleased with this purchase, they do everything i wanted them to do. One con is the control buttons, I'm not agile enough to tell what the buttons are without taking them off and looking at the headset.  Also a mute button would be handy for the commercials or if someone wanted to talk to you. I think a solution would be to purchase those sticky backed rubber bumpers that go on kitchen doors. You could stick one on the plus and minus volume buttons and then be able to feel them without looking.They were easy to set up with my newer Samsung TV. I didn't know you had to peel the plastic knobs off that protect the ends of the optical cable so that baffled me for a little bit. This only shows my lack of technical knowledge yet i bumbled my way through in short order and got them working.

Title: Sennheiser RS 175 RF Wireless Headphone System

Review Contents: This will be the second poor review of the Sennheiser brand from me and I am loath to give it. Besides the name being just damn cool, Sennheiser was a company I had always been able to rely on for a sound like no other. Now they are apparently attempting a new way to deliver on the Sennheiser promise. The sound promoted from This RS 175 is nearly Sennheiser studio sound - not audiophile. They still sound good. They pushed an audibly different sound than my last sets of Sennheiser phones however. I still have the last iterations (both wired and wireless) and during several side by side comparisons, the RS 175 are far more main stream sounding than previous generations and delivered a feeling of being boxed in. Thankfully my theater pre-amp has Dolby headphone which is pristine and opens up any set of headphones. The previous versions of Sennheiserâ€™s wireless headphones from the 165 and up were soft, controlled and accurate sounding with emphasis on breath and openness. No, the last iteration could not handle wide variations of bass, nor were they loud, but they sounded beautifully, and light as air when compared to the likes of - well - anything else wireless really. These new phones do not give that open sense without help.Considering they are wireless phones, they have a much wider volume span than in days of yore, heading north of comfortable if need be. They also handled harder base notes with more consideration and power, which I admit was a welcome change from previous releases. Turning on the incorporated bass management however, sent them into kiddie-boom mudslinging territory during the last TRON movie and added hard hoofing to anything already booming. It added artificial mass to voices during SVU streamed and The Walking Dead that were already deep... I have no want of such things so I keep it deactivated.The RS-175, does not decode surround of any kind so any optical data sent to this unit must be two channel audio which brings us to my next gotcha. This unit is supposed to be a surround headphone to use during movies and video etc. so why not down mix a surround signal to two channel? Who uses non surround fiber channel during surround? What fiction is Sennheiser trying to sell here? I could not even pass two channel decoded Dolby to the unit; instead running the headphone out to the analog in. I have yet to get ANY optical signal to work with this unit encoded or not. Instead It has two settings for surround built in which are unrelated to Dolby or DTS; One was a kind of light hall surround and the next was an expansive hall echo-chamber sound. Luckily for me again, I have Dolby Headphone surround from my pre-amp which is quite superior to the effect invoked on these phones. I leave the effect from the RS 175 off.Above all of that nonsense is the following notable extreme problem: THEY ARE NOT COMFORTABLE... These phones are too tight against my head and unrelenting with metal bands in either side adjuster. They will not be breaking in to fit a noggin any time soon. For that much money I expected them to fit securely but lightly and softly on my head as so many other versions have. The ear pads themselves are soft and forgiving but the pressure reminds me of their newer HD 380 Pro which is so tight I can only use them for skirmishes with sound recording after which I must take a break. These are almost that snug - ouch. I HAVE A MEDIUM-HAT CRANIUM. I wear a medium helmet from most brands of motorcycle helmets. My hats are medium and I adjust them down (tighten). My ears do fit within these headphones so that is a plus - I have medium ears which do not protrude from my head very far. Most brands of over ear/Circumpolar units fit around my ears. I usually only worry about the depth of the ear cups, these have enough clearance to not rest on my outer ear.To wrap this up, I think it might be worth it to hang on to them for a week but I will most likely be sending them back as unwearable for an entire movie. The sound is not advanced enough to demand such a price and certainly the lack of comfort dismisses the price as well.A pose to Sennheiser: ruining a great name is easy; making money is easy. Delivering on a promise clearly makes you queasy.
Title: Go ahead Sennheiser - keep screwing with your sound and comfort.

After charging for several hours, it took about 30 minutes for the headphones to properly configure to the TV.I can say these headphones have awesome sound quality.  There is a bass boost switch as well as surround sound option on the base and the headphones.  The controls are large buttons and very easy to use.They are mostly comfortable to wear but you must get used to having them completely surround your ears as opposed to sitting on top of them.I had read reviews where some people had complained about them not fitting larger heads but we don't find that to be the case at all. Title: Love this! My husband can watch his tv shows ...

Review Contents: At first I was hesitant to put this much money into headphones, but they have proven to be worth it.I was surprised at the sound isolation they provide. Dishes are getting done, kids are getting yelled at, etc... I'm oblivious to it all.These will never match a true surround sound system with external subwoofer, but I've been impressed with what they do offer. You definitely get the bass coming through, and just yesterday I was watching a show and heard a sound coming somewhat from behind me. This was actually unexpected because I was not expecting ANY surround sound.I've used these for about 2 months now, usually when I want to watch TV after my wife is sleeping in the next room. They are big enough to fit over my ears and not cause any kind of discomfort from pinching. I've used these for hours at a time without issue. Sometimes I'll pause the TV for a bit to work on my laptop for a bit, and I don't even bother to take them off. If I want to watch a cnn video or something, I have to take them off so I can actually hear it (did I mention great sound isolation?).I don't always put them back on the base after watching TV. They auto shutoff after some period of no signal. I've never had a problem with the battery to date.

Title: I really like the Sennheiser headphones this is the fourth pair we ...

Review Contents: After opening the exotic packaging I was dismayed at the fragile feeling of the headphones and base station. I had a use outdoors, to monitor a live concert where the audience was positioned across a pond, 140 ft the stage. In the description the range was spec'd as 300 ft so it seemed there would be no problems. However, write ups, product descriptions and specs can, and often are misleading especially in consumer electronics. So I thought it best to test, before deploying in a critical use. I set the station up atop my mail box with an mp3 player, on a clear sunny day and walked down the paved roadway, which curved conveniently to ensure a perfect line of sight view from transmitter to headphones. Alas, I only on got 130 ft before the first drop out and by 150 ft the signal was gone completely. Measurements were made line of sight with laser tape measure accurate to a couple of inches. In doors I notice the range was much less only going thru a couple of walls. Sound quality was good and they could get plenty loud, but the lack of robustness in the construction would not support rigors of out door festivals. Better to stick with Sennheiser's pro-line of wireless IEM.

Just remind him he can't laugh at the show because I can hear that. EQUIPMENT INFO:  Unless you have a new new TV you will need to get the Digital to Analog RCA Audio converter. Even if you have a new new TV you will want to get the converter. While it says it fits all digital TV's it does not.  This isn't their fault its due to so many different brands of TVs on the market. We all have recent TVs within the last 2 years since being purchased and the digital cord either didn't work or didn't fit. The converter with the converter cables are only around 10 bucks so go ahead and get them to save downtime. Very happy with these and I have recommended them to numerous other ladies. I ordered one day and with Amazon Prime i had them 2 days later.

Review Contents: They sound fantastic...I have some fairly high end wired headphones and these sound just as good or better.  Well worth the price, wireless works great, they sound great, and they're comfortable to wear for long periods.
Title: They sound fantastic..

Review Contents: Pros:Very convenient when watching movies or listening to music while walking around. Great audio quality, headphones are comfortable and do not put any pressure on the ears, so I can wear them for much longer than smaller on-ear ones. This model is closed, so it does not leak audio out -- not very important for me when I use them at home, but may be useful for some.Input switching is useful for my combination of computer output (SPDIF) and an audio system (analog jack), so I actually use it.There seem to be no problems with radio reception within range, and I have not yet got to the point when it ran out of battery.Cons:The ear pads are covered with thin synthetic leather, what is probably more durable, but less comfortable than velour version for RS185 -- I ended up buying those pads and use them in place of the original ones. I did not need RS185 features, so buying RS175 headphones and RS185 pads was for me a superior (and still cheaper) choice than RS185. Some may find it the other way around.Input switching control is only available as a slide switch on the back of the transmitter -- it would be better if it could be accessible from the headphones themselves instead of sound controls that I don't find to be of much use.Battery indicator, on the other hand, is only visible on the headphones themselves when they are not being charged -- it is not reported to the indicator on the transmitter, even though audio options are. (Edit -- indicator on the headphones does not show the battery state, only headphones being on or off, what is also visible on the transmitter. The battery state is only visible when headphones are being charged on the transmitter).

Review Contents: These headphones were fantastic till I noticed considerable pain at the back of my jaw line under my ears. I have never felt anything like this before but assumed I was getting used to the how tight these headphones clamp on your head. After a few days it became apparent I should stop using them as it continued to worsen. Since stopping two weeks ago, the aching sensation has alleviated but I still feel it from time to time whenever using my RS 170 (a feeling I have never had while using them over the past 3 years). Review Contents: I wanted to replace my very old, corded Koss Headphones. The ear pieces were hardened with age and very uncomfortable. These replacement headphones are a huge step up in performance. I was very impressed with the sound â€“ it is just crystal clear and sounds great for  a wireless system. It is so nice to not have a cord dangling from the headphones; I sometimes just forget that they are on my head.The setup is easy. Just connect the base to an outlet, connect an analog or optical digital source, insert the rechargeable batteries in the ear pieces by removing the ear pads, and set the headphones on the base to charge. After an initial recommended 16 hour charge, they are ready to use.The volume controls are on the right ear piece as are a surround button and a bass boost button. I found that the surround and bass effects are subtle, which I think is a good idea. I probably will just leave both of them off, since the sound is so good without any alteration. You get a quick start guide for setup, and a CD with the manual in PDF. The manual is quite comprehensive, and provides plenty of information on the use of the phones and troubleshooting.Overall, I would highly recommend these phones.

Review Contents: I'm a bit of audiophile, but not so snobby as to need the $300+ set of cans to be happy and when i say i was surprised with the quality of these RF headsets, i mean it.  I have tried RF before....years before and found them often lacking in quality and hated the dreaded hiss that seemed all too common.  With that said, i became a strictly wired cans person, but i have a friend who owned a pair of 170's and, after trying them, i decided to give RF another chance.The 175's are truly impressive for their price point.  Clean design, comfortable to wear, and the sound stage is robust, even compared to a few of wired options.  The ear cups do get a bit warm, but that was to be expected.  I tested these with bass heavy music, classical, and a few movies and i can't say i was displeased at any point.So, if you're in the market for a reasonable set of cans, buy now.  I am so pleased that I just bought a second system for my bedroom.

Title: great sound. controls are better and only one channel ...

Review Contents: I needed headphones to use with my new killer 4k home theater system since I live in a condo with paper-thin walls and and only have time to watch TV late at night. I also run Spotify on my HTS more than I watch Tv.  I purchased the rs175 and rs185 and compared over a week. The 185 sound is far superior. I thought I needed the bass boost and virtual surround effects the 175 has for music and movies...so  I was reluctant to consider the 185's. Well there is a reason those features aren't on the 185's...You don't need them! The natural unprocessed sound of the 185's is really that much better! Even so I wish they had a little more bass, but the bass, mid-tones, and highs "as is" are very rich, clear, and well balanced. The 175's sound was flat...and the bass was muddy and the mids and highs noticeably and almost uncomfortably harsh.  The only quirk for me is the open back so listening on the 185's isn't as private as the closed back 175's. But the 185's are also *much* more comfortable than the 175's, with super-soft microfiber earpads instead of the 175's "leatherette" (i.e. heat-trapping plastic) that made my ears feel hot and sweaty, so there's that plus too. Go with the 185's you won't be disappointed at all.

Review Contents: This is the most comfortable and most amazing pair of headphones I have ever had.  I do admit I am not a huge audiophile as some and have had luxury of purchasing a $300 headphones previously but I would say this is definitely worth it and I am glad I forked out that money.  Not only does the sound have better quality but with the surround sound enabled (I usually keep it at "low" which I find is the perfect level for most and "high" for music) it sounds like orchestra music is really playing right there.  This also gave me freedom from the earphone cable mess I had to deal with.  I bought audio cable extension and then I had to deal with it catching in the chair groove as part of the cable rested on the chair.My only issue has been not being able to use optical audio cable.  It doesn't feel like it fits well as it's supposed to on the TV.  But it could very well be issue with the TV as well.  after all, it's only Samsung.  They like to dance to the sound of their own

Title: As Expected

Review Contents: As an avid watcher of Downtown Abbey & Game of Thrones I needed these badly. I don't know about you - but as an American listening to BRITISH accented movies or TV shows I would often have a problem understanding 10% of the words because of the thick accented words. I used to watch GoT with CC on. Also i'd run into this problem with action movies and never fully hearing the words of what was being said over loud BOOMs and crashes. The only workaround was blasting my TV volume, and I live in the city in a condo so my neighbors probably wouldn't be happy with this.Secondly, living in a city I am surrounded by car alarms, dogs barking, babies screaming (new parents next door!) and construction sounds - to name a few. Putting these on is a nice way to escape from that. I can hear the TV crystal clear and was very surprised at how many subtle noises I heard now while wearing these.A few criticisms - the headphones ear cups get hot for me if I wear them longer than 2 hours. They are comfortable, but the body heat I produce make the plastic covering hot. This isn't a deal breaker. I have worn headphones for years for computer gaming and still have yet to find the "perfect headphone" that doesn't get hot.The base stand needs to be near your audio output. I have no problems with that, but the base stand is also your charger. If you, like me, have your audio output across the room, it means you have to get up, get your headphones, sit down, use them, and when done with them, get back up, walk over to the base stand and recharge the headphones. Yes, I know this is a "First World Problems" kind of thing, but I would have rather there was a design in which I could charge my headphones with another power cord closer to where I sit to watch TV. I could buy a digital audio cord that extends the base stand to where I sit, so its not the end of the world - just a buyer beware.Honestly, I should have bought something like this years ago. It really makes a huge difference when watching TV either by muting the rest of the outside world or by making it easier for you to watch TV and not bother anyone else.

Review Contents: I have been using the headset for several months and have been very pleased........... with one major exception.  The headset will not work streaming from Netflix and Amazon without a digital to analog decoder.  This fact is no where in the documentation provided nor on Sennheiser's website until you dig through the FAQs on their website.  Since streaming is normally a highly used capability by many,  Sennheiser needs to be upfront with this issue prior to purchase.I purchased the J-Tech Digital unit that Sennheiser recommended (stating they "tested it") on their website for streaming Amazon and Netflix as did a friend of mine.  Long story short it did not work on either of our systems.  The sound would echo and faded in and out after seeming to work at initial install.  The J-Tech unit is being returned as we speak.The headsets are great so long as you are not streaming Amazon, Netflix, etc.

He likes being able to turn up the volume and leave his hearing aids out without bothering the rest of the house. And even he appreciated the sound quality of a Sennheiser headset, saying they sound better than his old ones. I haven't had the pleasure of listening to them yet, he's become protective about this one...but I'm very happy about it and just glad he can enjoy his audio again without bothering everyone else in the house, and the houses next door.

Review Contents: I love almost everything about these headphones. There are several negatives: 1) the foam-filled ear pads wear hot. I've thought about fabricating cloth covers to insulate them from my head. 2) The battery takes a lot of time to recharge if it's fully drainedâ€”over-night may not be enough. 3) They don't feel, in a tactile sense, like headphones that cost the better part of $300. I realize weight is an issue, at least for the headphones themselves, but both the headphones and the recharging stand feel cheap. On the positive side, their fidelity is amazingâ€”clean, accurate sound, expansive sound stage, and excellent bass response that's never excessive. I also like their range. I can wear the headphones several rooms away from the recharging stand and still get great reception. Overall, these are very good wireless headphones.

Title: Great sound!

Review Contents: I normally don't write reviews, but I had to put one in for this product. Out of all the wireless stereo headphones that we have owned, these by far are the best.  I bought this product along with an extra set of headphones for my wife. Hooking them up was very simple, digital fiber optic plug works great.  Both headsets have near flawless surround sound and the bass is amazing.  The headphones are very comfortable and not too heavy.  So far we are able to walk around the entire inside of our house and even outside and we do not have any interference or lose any sound quality.  Simply amazing.For those people reviewing multiple headsets and complaining about not being able to charge them at the same time, there is a simple solution, buy a AAA battery charger that plugs into a wall and you can plug all the batteries into the charger, directly into the wall outlet and charge all the batteries at the same time.  Again we have owned many headsets and these are the best sound quality, comfortability, range, and no interference whatsoever.  Yes the price is kind of high, but you get what you pay for. I would recommend these headsets to anyone I know.

Review Contents: Neither the 'quick start' leaflet (provided) or the 'how to set up' Sennheiser video give any guidance on what to do if your TV does not have the recommended 'optical audio output'. And if your TV does not have an analogue receptacle you are really out of luck to get sound. But....if you are fortunate enough to have the analogue receptacle and use that option you will loose the sound from the TV so anyone else watching the program will need Closed Caption! A ridiculous situation and an issue Sennheiser need to address, And one thing more.....Neither the leaflet or video clearly indicate that the button on the right hand side of the right headset needs to be pressed and held for at least two seconds otherwise, again, no sound! I found that out through a You Tube video! The headphone works pretty well if you can wade through the aggravations mentioned but for the price of the darned things you'd think Sennheiser could spend a few cents on providing a decent operation guide.

Review Contents: The tl;dr is that these sound amazing, but there are ton of poor decisions in the physical design.  However it's currently the best option available if you want a charging stand.----I was looking for a pair of wireless headphones with a charging-stand.  However for some reason I could only find a handful of options.  After comparing literally all of them, I bought three headsets:* Sony MDR-RF985RK ($50)* Sennheiser RS 175 ($150)* Turtle Beach Elite 800 ($200)The Turtle Beach were painfully tight and had horrible non-stop static, so I returned them immediately.The Sony had the perfect physical-design but the audio quality was unacceptably bad.  I returned them as well.The Sennheiser's have great audio quality, but the physical-design is not good.  However, given my limited options I chose to keep them.PROS:* The audio sounds perfect* Wireless transmission is digital, meaning as you move away from the transmitter, you don't get increased static* Fantastic range.  I can walk around my entire house without losing the signal* Has a charging stand.  Why is this not more common!?!?* Wireless battery has good life.  I've used it for ~6 hours at a time with no issues.NEUTRAL:* Optical audio connection support.  I tried both the analog and digital, but couldn't hear a difference* Battery is NiMH.  Not sure why they didn't use LIon, which holds an even longer charge.CONS:* The headphones don't slide onto the charging stand, you need to line up the terminals manually.  This usually means placing the headphones on the stand, seeing that 'charging' light didn't turn on, then picking them up once or twice more and carefully placing them onto the terminals.In contrast, the Sony could literally be thrown on the stand and still start recharging every time.* You have to hold the power button down for 3 seconds to turn them on or off.  Why!?* If you take them off the stand and immediately hold down the power button, they won't turn on.  You need to wait ~2 seconds before holding the button down for another 3.  Why!?!?* The volume button are on the sides of the ear-pieces, meaning if you attempt to lie down while wearing them (to, say, watch a movie on the couch), you end up accidentally pressing the buttons 100% of the time.  The Sony one has them on the bottom of the ear cups* Completely unnecessary "extra bass" and "surround-sound" modes, which make the audio sound like crap.  Of course, the buttons for these are right next to the volume buttons, to ensure you accidentally turn them on often.* The ear cups themselves swivel around the head-band for unknown reasons.  The swivel-joint feels extremely flimsy, and I've heard multiple reports of it breaking.OVERALL:I really wish the Sony's used digital transmission that would reach across my house like these headphones; in that case I'd definitely choose those, because they have none of the "cons" above.  However, since they don't, I'm stuck with these.  The audio is great, but they made so SO many poor design decisions that I wonder how this ever made it through user-testing.For $150 I'd expect better, but these are still the best option I found, so until something better comes along, I'm keeping them.

Review Contents: Just received the Sennheiser RS 175 wireless unit in the mail. Set up using the optical cord on my 62" Hi-Def TV,, in seconds.. It took me longer to find the "On/Off" button than to install the whole system! (it's a small button in the lower part of the ear-muff, you have to push & hold it in for 3 seconds). It's that easy.. But does it work?I put on the ear-muffs, they were soft, comfortable, and the sound was simply unreal.. Then I pushed the "Surround Sound" button.. WOW!! It's like being in a 3-D theatre. And, you can turn them up to the point where it's deafening, or down to a 3-D whisper. I gave the muffs to my son and said: "Here, try these.." He put them on and stood mesmerized by a mere TV commercial.. These are the coolest things I've ever gotten.I gave this thing a 5-star rating because I can not find ONE THING wrong, or a thing that I would have done differently in design?The darn thing is perfect as far as I'm concerned.
Title: It's that easy.. But does it work

It's simply uncomfortable, to the point where I can't enjoy the music anymore.

The fit is also not as comfortable, but that may be my biased opinion. They do fit comfortably and remained so during extended periods of use. The range is excellent. It's great to be able to move room to room with these. Having the base double as a charging stand is another plus. Review Contents: I never did hear well on the left side, and the right ear is not getting younger.  That makes it hard for me to understand what is said on TV, even more because I emigrated and everything here is English and Spanish, not my native language.  For this reason I often refused when my wife proposed to watch a movie together.I received the headphones a few days ago and they do make a real difference. I can enjoy a movie now, without having to concentrate completely on what is said.  Before it was impossible for me to follow the movie when other persons started to talk in the living or dinner room, that's no longer a problem.  Of course it's a bit more difficult to share an opinion with someone while watching, but we can live with that.Setup was very easy.  The only "problem" was the sound of Netflix not coming true, but the Sennheiser manual tells how to change the settings of the TV to solve it.If you have the same hearing condition as me, or if you want to watch TV without disturbing or being disturbed, this headphones are a great tool.

Review Contents: Go this for my wife, as an upgrade to the Sennheiser RS-120's she has been using for TV watching.  She's not too particular about audio, so I wasn't sure if she would notice a difference.  After using the the RS-175 for about 30 seconds, she smiled and said "These are MUCH better!" :-).  <whew!>I've noticed that the RS-175 headphones also seal better around her ears than the headset from the RS-120 -- there is NO sound leaking out into the room, whereas there was a slight amount from the RS-120 headset.  Also, the receiver in the RS-120 headset had to be "tuned" to the base station, and that tuning was easy to upset by the wearer bumping the tuning knob while picking up or putting on the headset.  No tuning needed on the RS-175 (digital transmission, probably), so that's also no longer an issue.

Review Contents: Copied from my review of the headphones only:We have downsized our living quarters temporarily and loud sound is not an option. I purchased these headphones to replace our stereo system for the time being. They replace a 5.1 surround system that has served us faithfully for years. We are currently limited to our Cable service and the included music channels (and yes of course, the TV!).I have to say the sound quality, ease-of-use, and overall end result has been a surprise and a blessing. It has taken a bit of mucking around in the tv/ device/ headphone settings to get the overall stereo effect as accurate as we could, but that was expected. The Bass is rich and relatively tight, the mids are clear, and the high end is superb. We get sound all the way out to the kitchen 30ft away with no problem (yes, snack runs during commercials). I purchased a second pair of headphones for my wife and we have been loving them.

Review Contents: Handicapped product.  My TV is a year 2015 model which has default audio configuration "Bitstream" and Dolby surround sound.  When this headphone is connected with digital optical connection to the TV, there is no sound from the headphone.  I had to change the audio configuration to PCM to hear from the headphone, but this change messed up the TV use experience for the family when not using the headphone, as the TV now loses Dolby surround sound and the 2-channel PCM has lower quality.  How can this headphone sold in year 2018 be incompatible to an old TV manufactured in 2015?  As there is an obvious difference in quality between Bitstream/Dolby and PCM, has Sennheiser ever made an attempt regarding this problem for at least 3 years?

Review Contents: I just had opportunity to use my new headset (refurbished ones) and:- Less than refurbished, they look like used with labels / protectors.- I tried an 5.1 test video (audio basically) and the "surround" levels more than hear surrounding just add some reverbering and awful effect (very disappointed about this BTW)In the first try, I also noticed that the sound (connected by optical port) started going on and out... I was playing moving around the room and moving the base and in some cases the sound was fluid at all, but once I passed my room's door out the audio became a real disaster (no much problem because I really need them for watching TV)- I'm going to give another chance this night, and I hope not to have to take the decision to return them or rate lower than I'm doing it (actually I would like to rate higher after the second try)************* REVIEW UPDATE ***************Ok, as I said, I gave them a second chance:Drops out dissappear making a re-pairing of the head set with the base. Right now I'm walking (or rolling on my wheelchair) around the house and there is no audio drops out!I have never had premium headphones but, I think this are really premium on appearance and construction.The sound is great, but the sorround effects didn't convince me at all, so, I would give them 4 stars.

Review Contents: The instructions for set up are a bit muddy but I got it working. HOWEVER, as someone else noted it took close to 18 hours to charge the headset for my first use. Review Contents: My wife has 50% hearing loss in each ear.  After nearly 28 years of marriage, she expressed frustration with not being able to hear dialogue when the family watches tv together.  While these are more than I expected to spend, they have already been worth the expense.  Yesterday she commented about being able to hear the sound of broken glass crunching as a character in a show stepped on broken glass with his boots.  It was as if she had heard such detailed sounds for  the first time.  Only one word of caution.  With these on, don't expect to hear a phone ringing a few feet away or someone calling your name from the next room.

Title: Five Stars

Review Contents: Although pricey (maybe overpriced) this is a very high quality product. The clarity is astounding. I have hearing issues and these bring out background sounds that I cannot hear from the TV speakers or sound bar no matter how loud they are. There is no static or hiss ever (if you do not mind occasional hiss the RS-120 is an excellent alternative for about 1/4 the cost). I upgraded from the RS-120 because I thought over-ear phones would be much more comfortable than on-ear phones. They are more comfortable but still are too tight causing discomfort when wearing for more than 30 mins at a time. I do have a big head so this is part of the problem. I continuously stretch them out when not in use or charging. This has helped and the discomfort is worth it for the exceptional clarity.I always have the Bass function on. It does not muffle voices and add too much bass, but rather accents passages that are meant to have a strong bass line. I never use the Surround function because it does not seem to improve the presentation - just makes it sound different. I only use the phones within about 20-30 feet max of the transmitter and have no issues with reception.
Title: Astounding clarity but very pricey compared to the RS-120

This one cost more but it's worth the price.

Review Contents: First, let me say that I find reviews about service or non-product-related issues in product reviews very annoying. However, in this case I'm going to give myself license to list the good, the bad, and the perhaps slightly irrelevant all in one review. This is my second pair of Sennheiser headphones. I bought a pair for my hard-of-hearing mother a few years ago and they've been excellent. I purchased this second pair (different model) because these have an optical cable option and because I can pair a second set of headphones -- one each for me and my husband.Issue #1: The box had clearly been opened by someone prior to me receiving delivery. I don't mean the shipping box; I mean the product box. One of the accessory boxes had been torn open, the plastic bag containing the instructions had been opened, and ties on the optical cable had clearly been removed and carelessly replaced. However, it appeared that all parts were included and several parts were still in unopened plastic bags. The batteries were still in their original packaging. I did not order, nor did I pay for, an "open" package but that's clearly what I received.Issue #2: The optical cable is defective and clearly of inferior quality. If you purchase a set of these headphones do yourself a favor and just add a quality optical cable to your order. It took quite a bit of troubleshooting to figure out why the headphones weren't working (no sound). Luckily I had an optical cable for my sound bar. I was able to use that, reconfigure things, and determine that the provided optical cable was faulty.Issue #3: The rechargeable batteries provided are defective. Again, it took some troubleshooting to figure out why the headphones weren't working. Following the instructions, I installed the provided batteries and placed the headphones on the recharging stand for ~16 hours until the light turned green. Then I removed the headphones and started the process of testing for sound, etc. My first attempt didn't work (see cable issue above), so I turned off the TV, jiggled wires, etc. After less than 10 minutes of playing with the wires and buttons, etc (making sure I had the volume turned up and not muted), the power button turned off. I replaced the headphones on the charger and the light was red again. After 10 minutes?! I waited another 30 minutes but the headphones still had not charged to green again. At this point I dug out a set of non-rechargable AAA batteries, popped those in, and, with the new cable and the new batteries everything finally worked.In sum, Meh. They're headphones. They work (for now but I still have to get a new optical cable so I can wire my sound bar back up again). But they sure aren't anything special and they do not at all live up to what I expected based on the price and my previous Sennheiser experience. They do what they were supposed to do -- allow one (and hopefully, two) people to be able to watch TV while not disturbing the other people in the house trying to sleep or study. The Bass and Surround sound buttons do weird things to the sound that, to my ears, did nothing to enhance the experience. Maybe those are good for action movies? I tested them on a news program; the headphones certainly did not improve quality of the sound nor the quality of the news.As for comfort, I found them a bit heavy and I think they'll hurt my head after an hour or so but I think that's mostly an individual thing. I don't like wearing headphones in general and they all start to hurt after a while. The padding is nice and they fit around the ear and not over the ear so they do a pretty good job of buffering outside noise which allows one to keep the headphone volume to a minimum and avoid eardrum damage. But in terms of quality of sound or feel or buffering of outside noise I don't find these of any higher quality or any more comfortable than less expensive headphones I've owned over the years. The one thing these have over those others -- they're wireless.If I had to do all over again I'd probably avoid these and try a different model or maybe even a different brand. If you do buy these or similar headphones, either buy a better quality cable and a spare set of batteries or be prepared to acquire some in order to finish installation.I haven't received the companion headphones so I can't speak yet to how well they work or how it works to have two headphones working at the same time.

Review Contents: I love these headphones! They are a godsend to catching up with my shows and late night movies with my big screen tv when the wife and kids have gone to bed. I like the buttons on the ear up-easy to control and don't have to fiddle around much for the controls. Worth the price you pay. New loyal customer here for Sennheiser products.

Review Contents: Very disappointed with both audio performance and build quality of these headphones. They are made entirely of cheap plastic, the ear cushions are made of a material so thin I don't see how they will hold up to continued use without tearing. The fit was good and they seemed like they would be comfortable wearing for extended periods should you choose to keep them. I returned mine after two days. In my opinion based on build quality alone they are not worth $279. My intent for these headphones was going to be mainly for watching TV (optical out of TV to the transmitter optical input) and I thought it would be nice to not have to worry about the cord. I also didn't want to disturb my house-mates when watching TV. These headphones did seem to perform well when watching TV programming at moderate volume levels. Audio quality was good when listening to TV shows, Netflix, Amazon Prime, that were mostly dialog driven. Voices were clear and discernible, you could hear a lot of detail like things going on in the background, etc. However, when I listened to some more demanding soundtracks that were louder, or if I just turned up the volume then I lost the imaging and sound staging and the sound just gelled together. Listening to uncompressed FLAC music files is where these headphones really fell short in performance. There was no midrange warmth or bass extension, no pace, everything just sounded flat. My Audio-Technica ATH-M50 headphones (I think I paid around $140 for mine) being fed by an Audio Engine D1 USB headphone DAC outperformed the RS-175's in every possible way. The Surround modes were essentially useless, the LO setting did enhance voices (dialog) bringing it more forward in the head space while the Hi setting just produced an unrealistic reverberation and didn't really create an in-your-head surround sound experience. The bass boost really just overemphasized the bass response at higher volumes although at lower levels it did provide some needed bass much like the Loudness controls on AV receivers are intended to do. Also, as a closed back design these headphones leaked way to much sound out which negated my trying not to disturb others with my TV viewing. Some people might place more weight on the convenience of the wireless aspect of these cans and find the audio performance shortcomings an acceptable tradeoff but I just couldn't justify the cost of these headphones for the performance I was getting.

Title: Five Stars

Review Contents: I bought this ones over the RS 185 because they where cheaper and because of the surround sound and bass features. While I can say that the product sounds good when plugged in with the optical cable to my on-board motherboard sound card, the sound quality is completely lost when using the analog cable, and a predominant hiss and static noise is clearly audible. I do not think is my on-board sound card because my motherboard is premium and sports the SupremeFX Formula 2014 audio from ASUS ROG, which is the best ASUS has to offed for the Z97 generation of motherboards.The bass is good and punchy as advertised but the Surround Sound feature is mediocre, voices get distorted and sound hollow and digital as if an android or a Synth from Fallout 4 was talking, and a hiss and static noise becomes prominent when using the high surround sound setting. As for comfort, i can't complaint, they are comfortable but there is some heat buildup over time, and they can get a little painful after an hour of use as well.For Built quality man, despite being mostly plastic they still feel study and resilient, no complains there.What did scared me when I got them was that the plastic band that acts as a seal for the box was removed, and some of the bags for the accessories seemed to have been tampered with. My first thought was that it was probably done to check the product but it wasn't long before i was looking for the Sennheiser QR code to make sure it wasn't a fake. Luckily i found it and the authentication website said it was authentic but the fact that the seal was missing still bothers me. I bought this directly from Amazon which is listed as a Sennheiser certified dealer, not a third party that sells through Amazon.Conclusion.The headphones look splendid, feel like a premium product, and sound good (on occasion).Sadly their poor performance with the analog cable and the surround feature are too much to pass, since Sennheiser advertise this headphones as as being static noise free and honestly I expected better of the surround. I am pretty sure my devise is one of a few that isn't performing to Sennheiser's standards for X or Y reason. I emailed Sennheiser about the issues and hopefully they will help me troubleshoot this problems, but I do not know it it is too late, since I have already packed all the accessories back in their boxes.I will let the headphones finish charging and see if anything improves (which i hope), if nothing improves i will be returning these on Tuesday at the latest and will be getting the RF 185
Title: Bad luck? or buyer beware?

Review Contents: I need to concentrate in a sometimes noisy office environment. I had a previous model (RS-140) for years, and the battery finally died on them.The sound quality is MUCH improved (no hiss), but the design is in many ways a step backwards from the RS-140.#1 You must press and HOLD a small button for *several* seconds on the side of the headphones to turn them on (The RS-140 came one as soon as they were lifted from the cradle). This is annoying as the headphones turn off whenever they are placed in the cradle. I don't want to have to stare at my headphones for 3-5 seconds to see when the green light comes on every time I put them on.#2 The contacts on the cradle are too small (the coupling is just badly done).  I constantly have to 'wrestle' the headphones onto the stand to actually make contact, or more likely I put them on the cradle and don't realize that it didn't make contact, and so the headphones don't charge.Sennheiser if you are listening: these headphones really need to have a physical on/off instead of instead of a button-hold on/off. That was just a bad (dumb) design choice and is my major complaint. The headphones sound awesome, but the controls are horrible.

Review Contents: I had a little extra money so I thought I would de-clutter my desk and get some high quality headphones at the same time. I had already picked out a pair of headphones from another maker when my Audiophile co-worker recommended Sennheiser. I checked them out online and the seemed like a really high quality product and so, I decided to go with the RS 175 as it had the highest overall rating and all the reviews seemed to rave about them.When I received the headphones over the weekend, they looked nice, Good packaging and easy installation. I charged them overnight, plugged them into my home computer and fired them up. First thing I noticed was that they didn't work with the switch in the "Digital" position. Which I thought was odd but didn't mind too much, Switched it to analog and we were off to the races. the music came though loud and clear. I spent the next few hours walking around the house doing chores with these on my head. That's where the trouble started.After the first song ended, I noticed that in the dead space there was a very loud and hissing sound like static from an old TV.  The next song that played (Pandora) was a much softer song and I could hear the hissing over the music. I tried using the SURR and the BASS but NOTHING got rid of it. To be honest, I never did figure out what either of these buttons did as they didn't appear to have any noticeable affect on the music. I even tried them on different types of music and couldn't hear any difference. While I'm not a pure audiophile, I'm also not tone deaf and I heard NOTHING, not a lick of difference with the settings in different modes.I figured the hissing noise might be an issue with my home PC. But, when I plugged them in at the office, same thing. Maybe it's a problem with Pandora, same problem on YouTube and on Itunes.So, after 2 hour of listening while doing chores, the headphones stated to feel like a C clamp on my head and I finally had to take them off. When I brought them into the office I could make it about 5 minutes and my head and jaw started to hurt. So, I am returning them and will buy the manufacturer I had in mind to begin with.Really not a good experience with Sennheiser
